summary.long: Isaiah is a book of the Old Testament.

verses.text: This is the vision which Isaiah, son of Amoz, saw about Judah and Jerusalem at the time of Kings Uzziah, Jotham, Ahaz, and Hezekiah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Listen, heaven, and pay attention, earth!
    Yahweh has spoken,
        “I raised my children and helped them grow,
            but they have rebelled against me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Oxen know their owners,
    and donkeys know where their masters feed them.
    But Israel doesn’t know its owner.
    My people don’t understand who feeds them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“How horrible it will be for a nation that sins.
    Its people are loaded down with guilt.
        They are descendants of evildoers
            and destructive children.
    They have abandoned Yahweh.
    They have despised Qedosh Yisrael.
    They have turned their backs on him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Why do you still want to be beaten?
    Why do you continue to rebel?
    Your whole head is infected.
    Your whole heart is failing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
From the bottom of your feet to the top of your head
    there is no healthy spot left on your body—
        only bruises, sores, and fresh wounds.
            They haven’t been cleansed, bandaged,
                or soothed with oil.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Your country is devastated.
    Your cities are burned down.
    Your fields are destroyed right before your eyes by foreigners.
    Your fields are devastated and taken over by foreigners.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My people Zion are left like a hut in a vineyard,
    like a shack in a cucumber field,
    like a city under attack.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If Yahweh Tsebaoth hadn’t left us a few survivors,
    we would have been like Sodom and Gomorrah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Listen to the word of Yahweh, you rulers of Sodom!
    Pay attention to the teachings from our Elohim, you people of Gomorrah!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yahweh asks, “What do your many animal sacrifices mean to me?
    I’ve had enough of your burnt offerings of rams
        and enough fat from your fattened calves.
    I’m not pleased with the blood of bulls, lambs, or male goats.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When you appear in my presence,
    who asked you to trample on my courtyards?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Don’t bring any more worthless grain offerings.
    Your incense is disgusting to me,
    so are your New Moon Festivals, your days of worship,
        and the assemblies you call.
    I can’t stand your evil assemblies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I hate your New Moon Festivals and your appointed festivals.
    They’ve become a burden to me,
        and I’m tired of putting up with them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So when you stretch out your hands in prayer,
    I will turn my eyes away from you.
    Even though you offer many prayers,
    I will not listen because your hands are covered with blood.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Wash yourselves! Become clean!
    Get your evil deeds out of my sight.
    Stop doing evil.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Learn to do good.
    Seek justice.
    Arrest oppressors.
    Defend orphans.
    Plead the case of widows.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Come on now, let’s discuss this!” says Yahweh.
    “Though your sins are bright red,
    they will become as white as snow.
    Though they are dark red,
    they will become as white as wool.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If you are willing and obedient,
    you will eat the best from the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But if you refuse and rebel,
    you will be destroyed by swords.”
    Yahweh has spoken.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
How the faithful town has become a prostitute!
    She was full of justice,
        and righteousness lived in her.
            But now murderers live there!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your silver is not pure.
    Your wine is watered down.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your rulers are rebels, friends with thieves.
    They all love bribes and run after gifts.
    They never defend orphans.
    They don’t notice the widows’ pleas.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
That’s why Adonay, Yahweh Tsebaoth, the Mighty One of Israel, says,
“How horrible it will be when I take revenge on my opponents!
    I will avenge myself against my enemies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will turn my power against you.
    I will remove your impurities with bleach.
    I will get rid of all your impurities.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will give you judges like you had long ago,
    advisers like you had in the beginning.
    After that you will be called the Righteous City,
    the Faithful Town.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Zion will be pardoned by the Lord’s justice,
    and those who return will be pardoned
        by the Lord’s righteousness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Rebels and sinners will be crushed at the same time,
    and those who abandon Yahweh will come to an end.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You will be ashamed of the oaks that you wanted to worship
    and embarrassed by the garden that you have chosen for your gods.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You will be like an oak whose leaves wither
    and like a garden without water.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Strong people will become tinder for a fire,
    and their work will be the spark.
    Both of them will burn together,
    and there will be no one to put out the fire.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is the message which Isaiah, son of Amoz, saw about Judah and Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
In the last days the mountain of Yahweh’s house
    will be established as the highest of the mountains
        and raised above the hills.
            All the nations will stream to it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then many people will come and say,
    “Let’s go to the mountain of Yahweh,
        to the house of the Elohim of Jacob.
            He will teach us his ways so that we may live by them.”
    The teachings will go out from Zion.
    The word of Yahweh will go out from Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then he will judge disputes between nations
    and settle arguments between many people.
    They will hammer their swords into plowblades
        and their spears into pruning shears.
    Nations will never fight against each other,
        and they will never train for war again.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Come, descendants of Jacob,
    let’s live in the light of Yahweh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yahweh, you have abandoned your people, the descendants of Jacob,
    because they are filled with Eastern influences.
        They are fortunetellers like the Philistines,
            and they make deals with foreigners.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Their land is filled with silver and gold,
    and there is no end to their treasures.
    Their land is filled with horses,
        and there is no end to their chariots.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Their land is filled with idols,
    and they worship what their hands have shaped
        and what their fingers have molded.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
People will be brought down. Everyone will be humbled.
    Do not forgive them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Go in among the rocks and hide underground
    because of Yahweh’s terrifying presence
        and the honor of his majesty.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The eyes of arrogant people will be humbled.
    High and mighty people will be brought down.
    On that day Yahweh alone will be honored.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yahweh Tsebaoth will have his day
    against all who are arrogant and conceited
        and all who are proud of themselves (they will be humbled),
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
against all the towering and mighty cedars of Lebanon
    and all the oaks of Bashan,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
against all the high mountains
    and all the lofty hills,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
against every high tower
    and every fortified wall,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
against all the large ships of Tarshish
    and all the beautiful boats.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then arrogant people will be brought down,
    and high and mighty people will be humbled.
        On that day Yahweh alone will be honored.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then idols will disappear completely.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
People will go into caves in the rocks
    and into holes in the ground
        because of Yahweh’s terrifying presence
            and the honor of his majesty
                when he rises to terrify the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
On that day people will throw to the moles and the bats
    the silver and gold idols that they made
        for themselves to worship.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They will go into caves in the rocks
    and into cracks in the cliffs
        because of Yahweh’s terrifying presence
            and the honor of his majesty
                when he rises to terrify the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Stop trusting people.
    Their life is in their nostrils.
        How can they be worth anything?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
See now, Adonay, Yahweh Tsebaoth,
    is going to take from Jerusalem and Judah
        every kind of support
            and their entire supply of food and water.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He will take their heroes and soldiers,
    judges and prophets,
        fortunetellers and statesmen,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
military leaders and civilian leaders,
                counselors, skilled workers, and experts in magic.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“I will make boys their leaders.
    Children will govern them.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
People will oppress each other,
    and everyone will oppress his neighbor.
    The young will make fun of the old,
    and common people will make fun of their superiors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A person will grab one of his relatives
    from his father’s family and say,
        “You have a coat.
            You’ll be our leader.
                This pile of ruins will be under your control.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When that day comes the relative will cry out,
    “I’m not a doctor!
    I don’t have any food or a coat in my home.
        Don’t make me a leader of our family.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Jerusalem has stumbled, and Judah has fallen,
    because what they say and what they do is against Yahweh.
        They are defiant in his honored presence.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The look on their faces will be held against them.
    They boast about their sins,
    which are like those of the people of Sodom.
    They don’t even bother to hide them.
    How horrible it will be for these people,
    because they have brought disaster on themselves.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Tell the righteous that blessings will come to them.
    They will taste the fruit of their labor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
How horrible it will be for the wicked! Disaster will strike them.
    What they have done will be done to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Children will oppress my people.
    Women will rule them.
        My people, your guides mislead you,
            and you don’t know which way to go.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yahweh takes his place in the courtroom.
    He stands to judge his people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yahweh presents his case to the respected leaders
    and the officials of his people:
        “You have burned down the vineyard!
            Your houses are filled with goods stolen from the poor.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Adonay Yahweh Tsebaoth asks,
    “How can you crush my people
        and grind the faces of the poor into the ground?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yahweh adds,
    “The women of Zion are arrogant.
        They walk with their noses in the air,
            making seductive glances,
            taking short little steps,
            jingling the ankle bracelets on their feet.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Adonay will cause sores to appear
    on the heads of the women of Zion,
        and Yahweh will make their foreheads bare.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On that day Adonay will take away their fine things: jingling anklets, headbands, crescent-shaped necklaces,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: pendants, bracelets, scarfs,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: hats, ankle bracelets, blouses, perfume boxes, charms,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: signet rings, nose rings,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: fine robes, coats, shawls, purses,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: mirrors, underwear, headdresses, and veils.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Instead of the smell of perfume, there will be the smell of decay.
    They will wear ropes instead of belts.
    They will have bald heads instead of beautiful hair.
    They will wear sackcloth instead of expensive clothes.
        Their beauty will be scarred.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Women, your warriors will die in combat.
    Your mighty men will die in battle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The gates of Zion will cry and grieve,
    and Zion will sit on the ground, exhausted.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When that day comes, seven women will grab one man and say,
    “We’ll eat our own food and provide our own clothes.
        Just let us marry you for your name.
            Take away our disgrace.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When that day comes, the branch of Yahweh
    will be beautiful and wonderful.
        The fruit of the land
            will be the pride and joy of Israel’s survivors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then whoever is left in Zion and whoever remains in Jerusalem will be called holy, everyone who is recorded among the living in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Adonay will wash away the filth of Zion’s people. He will clean bloodstains from Jerusalem with a spirit of judgment and a spirit of burning.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yahweh will create a cloud of smoke during the day and a glowing flame of fire during the night over the whole area of Mount Zion and over the assembly. His glory will cover everything.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It will be a shelter from the heat during the day as well as a refuge and hiding place from storms and rain.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Let me sing a lovesong to my beloved about his vineyard:
My beloved had a vineyard on a fertile hill.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He dug it up, removed its stones,
    planted it with the choicest vines,
        built a watchtower in it,
            and made a winepress in it.
    Then he waited for it to produce good grapes,
        but it produced only sour, wild grapes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Now then, you inhabitants of Jerusalem and Judah,
    judge between me and my vineyard!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
What more could have been done for my vineyard
    than what I have already done for it?
    When I waited for it to produce good grapes,
    why did it produce only sour, wild grapes?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Now then, let me tell you what I will do to my vineyard.
    I will tear away its hedge so that it can be devoured
        and tear down its wall so that it can be trampled.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will make it a wasteland.
    It will never be pruned or hoed.
        Thorns and weeds will grow in it,
            and I will command the clouds not to rain on it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The vineyard of Yahweh Tsebaoth is the nation of Israel,
    and the people of Judah are the garden of his delight.
    He hoped for justice but saw only slaughter,
    for righteousness but heard only cries of distress.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
How horrible it will be for you
    who acquire house after house and buy field after field
        until there’s nothing left
            and you have to live by yourself in the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
With my own ears I heard Yahweh Tsebaoth say,
    “Many houses will become empty.
    Large, beautiful houses will be without people to live in them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A ten-acre vineyard will produce only six gallons of wine,
    and two quarts of seed will produce only four quarts of grain.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
How horrible it will be for those
    who get up early to look for a drink,
    who sit up late until they are drunk from wine.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
At their feasts there are lyres and harps,
    tambourines and flutes, and wine.
        Yet, they don’t pay attention to what Yahweh is doing
            or see what his hands have done.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“My people will go into exile
    because they don’t understand what I’m doing.
        Honored men will starve,
            and common people will be parched with thirst.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
That is why the grave’s appetite increases.
    It opens its mouth very wide
        so that honored people and common people will go down into it.
            Those who are noisy and joyous will go down into it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
People will be brought down. Everyone will be humbled.
    And the eyes of arrogant people will be humbled.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yahweh Tsebaoth will be honored when he judges.
    The holy El will show himself to be holy when he does what is right.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then lambs will graze as if they were in their own pasture,
    and foreigners will eat among the ruins of the rich.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
How horrible it will be for those
    who string people along with lies and empty promises,
    whose lives are sinful.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They say,
    “Let Yahweh hurry and quickly do his work
        so that we may see what he has in mind.
            Let the plan of Qedosh Yisrael happen quickly
                so that we may understand what he is doing.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
How horrible it will be for those
    who call evil good and good evil,
    who turn darkness into light and light into darkness,
    who turn what is bitter into something sweet
        and what is sweet into something bitter.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
How horrible it will be for those
    who think they are wise
        and consider themselves to be clever.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
How horrible it will be for those
    who are heroes at drinking wine,
    who are champions at mixing drinks,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
who declare the guilty innocent for a bribe,
    who take away the rights of righteous people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
As flames burn up straw
    and dry grass shrivels in flames,
        so their roots will rot,
            and their blossoms will blow away like dust.
    They have rejected the teachings of Yahweh Tsebaoth
    and have despised the word of Qedosh Yisrael.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
That’s why the anger of Yahweh burns hot against his people,
    and he is ready to use his power to strike them down.
    The hills tremble,
    and dead bodies lie like garbage in the streets.
Even after all this, his anger has not disappeared,
    and he is still ready to use his power.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yahweh raises up a flag for the nations far away.
    With a whistle he signals those at the ends of the earth.
        Look, they are coming very quickly!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
None of them grow tired or stumble.
    None of them slumber or sleep.
    The belts on their waists aren’t loose
        or their sandal straps broken.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Their arrows are sharpened; all their bows are ready to shoot.
    Their horses’ hoofs are as hard as flint.
    Their chariot wheels are as quick as the wind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They roar like a lioness.
    They growl like a young lion.
    They growl as they snatch their prey
    and carry it off to where no one can rescue it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
On that day they will roar over their prey
    as the sea roars.
    If they look at the land,
    they will see only darkness and distress.
    Even the light will be darkened by thick clouds.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the year King Uzziah died, I saw Adonay sitting on a high and lofty throne. The bottom of his robe filled the temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Angels were standing above him. Each had six wings: With two they covered their faces, with two they covered their feet, and with two they flew.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They called to each other and said,
“Holy, holy, holy is Yahweh Tsebaoth!
    The whole earth is filled with his glory.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Their voices shook the foundations of the doorposts, and the temple filled with smoke.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So I said, “Oh, no!
I’m doomed.
    Every word that passes through my lips is sinful.
        I live among people with sinful lips.
            I have seen the Melek, Yahweh Tsebaoth!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then one of the angels flew to me. In his hand was a burning coal that he had taken from the altar with tongs.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He touched my mouth with it and said, “This has touched your lips. Your guilt has been taken away, and your sin has been forgiven.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then I heard the voice of Adonay, saying, “Whom will I send? Who will go for us?”
I said, “Here I am. Send me!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
And he said, “Go and tell these people,
‘No matter how closely you listen, you’ll never understand.
    No matter how closely you look, you’ll never see.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Make these people close-minded.
    Plug their ears.
        Shut their eyes.
            Otherwise, they may see with their eyes,
        hear with their ears,
    understand with their minds,
        and return and be healed.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I asked, “How long, O Adonay?”
And he replied,
“Until the cities lie in ruins with no one living in them,
    the houses have no people,
        and the land is completely desolate.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yahweh will send his people far away,
    and a large area in the middle of the land will be abandoned.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Even if one out of ten people is left in it,
    the land will be burned again.
        When a sacred oak or an oak is cut down, a stump is left.
            The holy seed will be the land’s stump.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Ahaz, son of Jotham and grandson of Uzziah, was king of Judah, Aram’s King Rezin and Israel’s King Pekah, son of Remaliah, went to Jerusalem to attack it, but they couldn’t defeat it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When word reached David’s family that the Arameans had made an alliance with Ephraim, the hearts of the king and his people were shaken as the trees of the forest are shaken by the wind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Yahweh said to Isaiah, “Go out with your son Shear Jashub to meet Ahaz at the end of the ditch of the Upper Pool on the road to the Laundryman’s Field.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Say to him, ‘Be careful, stay calm, and don’t be afraid. Don’t lose heart because of the fierce anger of Rezin from Aram and Remaliah’s son. These two are smoldering logs.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Aram, Ephraim, and Remaliah’s son have planned evil against you, saying,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Let’s march against Judah, tear it apart, divide it among ourselves, and set up Tabeel’s son as its king.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is what Adonay Yahweh says:
It won’t take place; it won’t happen.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The capital of Aram is Damascus,
    and the leader of Damascus is Rezin.
        Ephraim will be shattered within 65 years
            so that it will no longer be a nation.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The capital of Ephraim is Samaria,
    and the leader of Samaria is Remaliah’s son.
        If you don’t remain faithful,
            you won’t remain standing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Again Yahweh spoke to Ahaz,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Ask Yahweh your Elohim for a sign. It can be anything you want.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Ahaz answered, “I won’t ask; I wouldn’t think of testing Yahweh.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Listen now, descendants of David,” Isaiah said. “Isn’t it enough that you try the patience of mortals? Must you also try the patience of my Elohim?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Adonay himself will give you this sign: A virgin will become pregnant and give birth to a son, and she will name him Immanuel [God Is With Us].
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He will eat cheese and honey until he knows how to reject evil and choose good.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Indeed, before the boy knows how to reject evil and choose good, the land of the two kings who terrify you will be deserted.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Yahweh will bring on you, your people, and your ancestor’s family a time unlike any since Ephraim broke away from Judah. He will bring the king of Assyria.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On that day Yahweh will whistle for the flies that are at the distant branches of the Nile River in Egypt and for the bees that are in Assyria.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All of them will come and settle in the deep valleys, in the cracks in the cliffs, on all the thornbushes, and at all the water holes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “On that day Adonay will hire the king of Assyria from beyond the Euphrates River to be a razor to shave the hair on your head, the hair on your legs, and even your beard.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On that day a person will keep alive a young cow and two sheep.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That person will eat cheese, because they will produce so much milk. Everyone who is left in the land will eat cheese and honey.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On that day, in every place where there were 1,000 vines (worth 1,000 pieces of silver), there will be briars and thorns.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: People will come there with bows and arrows to hunt because the whole land will be filled with briars and thorns.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And you will no longer be able to go to all the hills which used to be cultivated because they will be filled with briars and thorns. It will be a place for turning oxen loose and letting sheep run.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yahweh said to me, “Take a large writing tablet, and write on it with a pen: ‘Maher Shalal Hash Baz’ [The Looting Will Come Quickly; the Prey Will Be Easy].
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will have these dependable witnesses testify: the priest Uriah and Zechariah (son of Jeberechiah).”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I slept with the prophet. She became pregnant and gave birth to a son. Yahweh told me, “Name him Maher Shalal Hash Baz.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Before the boy knows how to say ‘Daddy’ or ‘Mommy,’ the wealth of Damascus and the loot from Samaria will be carried away to the king of Assyria.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yahweh spoke to me again. He said,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“These people have rejected the gently flowing water of Shiloah
    and find joy in Rezin and Remaliah’s son.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
That is why Adonay is going to bring against them
    the raging and powerful floodwaters of the Euphrates River—
        the king of Assyria with all his power.
    It will overflow all its channels and go over all its banks.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
It will sweep through Judah.
    It will overflow and pass through; it will be neck-high.
    Its outspread wings will extend over your whole country, O Immanuel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Be broken, you people. Be terrified.
    Listen, all you distant parts of the earth.
    Prepare for battle, but be terrified.
    Prepare for battle, but be terrified.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Make plans for battle, but they will never succeed.
    Give orders, but they won’t be carried out,
        because El is with us!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is what Yahweh said with his powerful hand on me.
He warned me not to follow the ways of these people:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Don’t say that everything these people call a conspiracy
    is a conspiracy.
    Don’t fear what they fear.
    Don’t let it terrify you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Remember that Yahweh Tsebaoth is holy.
    He is the one you should fear
        and the one you should be terrified of.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He will be a place of safety for you.
    But he will be a rock that makes people trip
        and a stumbling block for both kingdoms of Israel.
        He will be a trap and a snare for those who live in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Many will stumble.
            They will fall and be broken.
            They will be trapped and caught.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Tie up the written instructions.
    Seal the teachings among my disciples.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will wait for Yahweh,
    who hides his face from the descendants of Jacob.
    I will hope in him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I am here with the children that Yahweh has given me.
    We are signs and symbols in Israel
        from Yahweh Tsebaoth, who lives on Mount Zion.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
People will say to you, “Ask for help from the mediums
    and the fortunetellers, who whisper and mutter.”
    Shouldn’t people ask their Elohim for help instead?
    Why should they ask the dead to help the living?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They should go to the teachings and to the written instructions.
    If people don’t speak these words,
        it is because it doesn’t dawn on them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They will pass through the land when they are hard-pressed and hungry.
    When they are hungry, they will be furious.
        Then they will look up, cursing their king and Elohim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They will look at the earth and see only distress and gloom.
    They will go in anguish and be forced into darkness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But there will be no more gloom
    for the land that is in distress.
    Elohim humbled the lands of Zebulun and Naphtali in earlier times.
    But in the future he will bring glory to the road by the sea,
        to the land across the Jordan River,
        to Galilee, where foreigners live.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The people who walk in darkness will see a bright light.
    The light will shine on those who live in the land of death’s shadow.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You will expand the nation and increase its happiness.
    It will be happy in your presence
        like those who celebrate the harvest
            or rejoice when dividing loot.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You will break the yoke that burdens them,
    the bar that is across their shoulders,
        and the stick used by their oppressor,
            as you did in the battle against Midian.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Every warrior’s boot marching to the sound of battle
    and every garment rolled in blood
        will be burned as fuel in the fire.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A child will be born for us.
    A son will be given to us.
    The government will rest on his shoulders.
    He will be named:
        Wonderful Counselor,
        Mighty God,
        Everlasting Father,
        Sar Shalom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
His government and peace will have unlimited growth.
    He will establish David’s throne and kingdom.
    He will uphold it with justice and righteousness now and forever.
    Yahweh Tsebaoth is determined to do this!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Adonay sent a message against Jacob.
    The message is against Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
All the people of Ephraim
    and the people who live in Samaria will know it.
        With arrogant and conceited hearts they will say,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Bricks have fallen,
    but we will rebuild with hand-cut stones.
        Fig trees have been cut down,
            but we will replace them with cedars.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yahweh will set Rezin’s oppressors against Israel
    and will stir up its enemies—
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
the Arameans from the east and the Philistines from the west.
    They will devour Israel with open mouths.
Even after all this, his anger will not disappear,
    and he is still ready to use his power.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But the people have not returned to the one who struck them,
    nor have they sought Yahweh Tsebaoth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So in one day Yahweh will cut off from Israel
    both head and tail,
    both palm branches and cattails.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Respected and honored leaders are the head.
    Prophets who teach lies are the tail.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Those who guide these people lead them astray.
    Those who are guided by them will be destroyed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
That is why Adonay isn’t happy with their young men,
    nor will he show compassion for their orphans and widows.
        Every one of them is a godless evildoer,
            and every mouth speaks foolishness.
Even after all this, his anger will not disappear,
    and he is still ready to use his power.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Surely wickedness burns like fire.
    It burns up briars and thorns.
    It sets the underbrush in the forest on fire,
        and it whirls upward in clouds of smoke.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The land is scorched by the fury of Yahweh Tsebaoth,
    and the people are like fuel for the fire.
    No one shows concern for others:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
On the right, one gobbles up food and is still hungry.
    On the left, another eats and is never full.
        Each person eats the flesh from his own arm.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Manasseh is against Ephraim.
    Ephraim is against Manasseh.
    Together they attack Judah.
Even after all this, his anger will not disappear,
    and he is still ready to use his power.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
How horrible it will be for those who make unjust laws
    and who make oppressive regulations.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They deprive the poor of justice.
        They take away the rights of the needy among my people.
        They prey on widows and rob orphans.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
What will you do on the day
    you are called to account for these things,
        when the disaster comes from far away?
    Where will you run for help?
    Where will you leave your wealth?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Nothing’s left but to crouch among prisoners
    and to fall with those who are killed.
Even after all this, his anger will not disappear,
    and he is still ready to use his power.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“How horrible it will be for Assyria!
    It is the rod of my anger.
        My fury is the staff in the Assyrians’ hands.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I send them against a godless nation.
    In my fury I order them against the people
    to take their belongings, loot them,
        and trample on them like mud in the streets.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But that’s not what they intend to do.
    Their minds don’t work that way.
    Their purpose is to destroy and put an end to many nations.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They ask, ‘Aren’t all our commanders kings?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Isn’t Calno like Carchemish?
    Isn’t Hamath like Arpad?
    Isn’t Samaria like Damascus?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My power has reached kingdoms which have idols.
    They had more carved statues than Jerusalem or Samaria.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will do to Jerusalem and its idols
    what I’ve done to Samaria and its idols.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Adonay has finished all his work on Mount Zion and in Jerusalem, he will punish the king of Assyria for all his boasting and all his arrogance.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The king will say,
“I did this with my own two powerful hands.
    I did this with my wisdom, because I am so clever.
    I’ve eliminated the boundaries of nations.
    I’ve looted treasuries.
    I’ve brought down people like a mighty man.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I’ve found the riches of nations as one finds a nest.
    I’ve gathered the whole world as one gathers abandoned eggs.
    Not one of them flapped a wing, opened its mouth, or peeped.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Can an ax attack the person who cuts with it?
    Can a saw make itself greater than the person who saws with it?
    A rod cannot move the person who lifts it.
    A wooden stick cannot pick up a person.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
That is why Adonay Yahweh Tsebaoth
    will send a degenerative disease against brave men.
        A flame will be turned into a raging fire under his power.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Israel’s light will become a flame.
    Its Holy One will become a fire.
    He will burn up and devour the weeds and thornbushes in one day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The majestic forest and the orchard
    will destroy both body and soul.
    They will be like a sick person wasting away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The trees that remain in the forest will be so few that
    a child could count them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
At that time the remaining few Israelites,
    the survivors of Jacob’s descendants
        will no longer depend on the one who struck them.
            They will only depend on Yahweh, Qedosh Yisrael.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A few, the remaining few of Jacob, will return to the mighty God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Although your people Israel may be
    as numerous as the grains of sand on the seashore,
        only a few will return.
    Destruction will be complete and fair.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Adonay Yahweh Tsebaoth will carry out this destruction
    throughout the world as he has determined.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Adonay Yahweh Tsebaoth says:
    My people who live in Zion,
        don’t be afraid of the Assyrians when they strike with a rod
            or when they raise their staff against you
                as the Egyptians did.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Very soon I will unleash my fury,
    and my anger will destroy them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then Yahweh Tsebaoth will raise his whip against them.
    As he struck down Midian at the Rock of Oreb
        and raised his staff over the water,
            so he will lift it as he did in Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
At that time their burden will be removed from your shoulders.
    Their yoke will be removed from your neck.
        The yoke will be torn away because you have grown fat.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They come to Aiath.
    They pass through Migron.
        They store their equipment at Michmash.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They go through the mountain pass and lodge at Geba for the night.
    The people in Ramah tremble; the people in Saul’s Gibeah flee.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Cry aloud, you people in Gallim!
    Pay attention, you people in Laishah and miserable Anathoth!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people in Madmenah flee; those who live in Gebim take shelter.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This day they stopped at Nob.
    They shake their fist at the mountain of my people Zion,
        at the mountain of Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Now look! Adonay Yahweh Tsebaoth
    will trim the branches with terrifying power.
        The highest trees will be cut down.
        The tallest ones will be brought down.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He will cut down the underbrush of the forest with an ax.
    Lebanon will fall in front of the Mighty One.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then a shoot will come out from the stump of Jesse,
    and a branch from its roots will bear fruit.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Ruach Yahweh will rest on him—
    the Ruach of wisdom and understanding,
    the Ruach of advice and power,
    the Ruach of knowledge and fear of Yahweh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He will gladly bear the fear of Yahweh.
    He will not judge by what his eyes see
    or decide by what his ears hear.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He will judge the poor justly.
    He will make fair decisions for the humble people on earth.
    He will strike the earth with a rod from his mouth.
    He will kill the wicked with the breath from his lips.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Justice will be the belt around his waist.
    Faithfulness will be the belt around his hips.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Wolves will live with lambs.
    Leopards will lie down with goats.
    Calves, young lions, and year-old lambs will be together,
    and little children will lead them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Cows and bears will eat together.
    Their young will lie down together.
    Lions will eat straw like oxen.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Infants will play near cobras’ holes.
    Toddlers will put their hands into vipers’ nests.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They will not hurt or destroy anyone anywhere on my holy mountain.
    The world will be filled with the knowledge of Yahweh
        like water covering the sea.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
At that time the root of Jesse will stand as a banner
    for the people to gather around.
        The nations will come to him.
            His resting place will be glorious.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
At that time Adonay will use his power again
    to recover what remains of his people
        in Assyria, Upper and Lower Egypt,
            Sudan, Elam, Babylonia, Hamath,
                and the islands of the sea.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He will raise a banner for the nations to gather around.
    He will gather the outcasts of Israel
    and bring together the scattered people of Judah
        from the four corners of the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Ephraim’s jealousy will vanish,
    and Judah’s opponents will come to an end.
    Ephraim won’t be jealous of Judah,
    and Judah won’t oppose Ephraim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They will swoop down on the slopes of Philistia in the west.
    Together they will loot the people of the east.
    They will conquer Edom and Moab.
    The people of Ammon will be subject to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yahweh will dry up the gulf of the Egyptian Sea.
    He will wave his hand over the Euphrates River with his scorching wind
    and divide it into seven streams
        so that people can walk over it in their sandals.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
There will be a highway
    for the remaining few of his people left in Assyria
        like there was for Israel when it came out of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
At that time you will say,
“I will praise you, O Yahweh.
    Although you had been angry with me,
    you turned your anger away from me, and you comforted me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Look! El is my Savior.
    I am confident and unafraid,
    because Yah is my strength and my song.
    He is my Savior.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: With joy you will draw water from the springs of salvation.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
At that time you will say,
“Praise Yahweh.
    Call on his name.
    Make his deeds known among the nations.
    Make them remember that his name is highly honored.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Make music to praise Yahweh.
    He has done wonderful things.
        Let this be known throughout the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Shout loudly, and sing with joy, people of Zion!
    Qedosh Yisrael is great. He is among you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is the divine revelation which Isaiah, son of Amoz, saw about Babylon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Raise a banner on the bare mountaintop.
    Call loudly to them.
        Signal them with your hand to enter the nobles’ gates.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I’ve commanded my holy ones.
    I’ve called my mighty men to carry out my anger.
    They find joy in my triumphs.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Listen to the noise on the mountains.
    It is like the sound of a large army.
    It is the sound of kingdoms and nations gathering together.
    Yahweh Tsebaoth is assembling his army for battle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
His army is coming from a distant land,
    from the ends of heaven.
    Yahweh is coming with the weapons of his fury
    to destroy the whole world.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Cry loudly, for the day of Yahweh is near.
    It will come like destruction from Shadday.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
That is why every hand will hang limp,
    and everyone’s courage will fail.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They’ll be terrified.
            Pain and anguish will seize them.
        They’ll writhe like a woman giving birth to a child.
        They’ll look at one another in astonishment.
            Their faces will be burning red.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The day of Yahweh is going to come.
    It will be a cruel day with fury and fierce anger.
        He will make the earth desolate.
            He will destroy its sinners.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The stars in the sky and their constellations
    won’t show their light anymore.
    The sun will be dark when it rises.
    The moon won’t shine.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will punish the world for its evil
    and the wicked for their wrongdoing.
    I will put an end to arrogant people
    and humble the pride of tyrants.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will make people harder to find than pure gold
    and human beings more rare than gold from Ophir.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will make heaven tremble,
    and the earth will be shaken from its place
        when Yahweh Tsebaoth is angry.
            At that time he will be very angry.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They’ll be like hunted gazelle
    and like sheep with no one to gather them.
    Everyone will return to his own people
    and flee to his own land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Whoever is found will be stabbed to death.
    Whoever is captured will be executed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Their little children will be smashed to death right before their eyes.
    Their houses will be looted and their wives raped.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I’m going to stir up the Medes against them.
    They don’t care for silver and aren’t happy with gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But their bows will smash the youth.
    They’ll have no compassion for babies,
        nor will they look with pity on children.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Babylon, the jewel of the kingdoms,
    the proud beauty of the Chaldeans,
        will be like Sodom and Gomorrah when Elohim destroyed them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
It will never be inhabited again,
    and no one will live in it for generations.
        Arabs won’t pitch their tents there.
        Shepherds won’t let their flocks rest there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Desert animals will lie down there.
    Their homes will be full of owls.
        Ostriches will live there,
            and wild goats will skip about.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Hyenas will howl in Babylon’s strongholds,
    and jackals will howl in its luxurious palaces.
Its time has almost come.
    Its days will not be extended.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yahweh will have compassion for Jacob and again choose Israel.
    He will resettle them in their own country.
        Foreigners will join them
            and unite with the descendants of Jacob.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
People will take them
    and bring them to their own place.
    The nation of Israel will possess nations
    as male and female slaves in Yahweh’s land.
    They will take their captors captive
    and rule their oppressors.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
Then you will mock the king of Babylon with this saying,
    “How the tyrant has come to an end!
    How his attacks have come to an end!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yahweh has broken the staff of the wicked,
    the scepter of rulers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They struck the people with fury,
            with blows that didn’t stop.
        They ruled nations in anger,
            persecuting them without restraint.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The whole earth rests and is peaceful.
    It breaks out into shouts of joy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Even the cypresses rejoice over you.
    The cedars of Lebanon say,
        “Since you have fallen,
            no lumberjack has come to attack us.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Sheol below wakes up to meet you when you come.
    It wakes up the ghosts of the dead,
        all who were leaders on earth.
    It raises all who were kings of the nations from their thrones.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
All of them will greet you,
    “You also have become weak like us!
    You have become like one of us!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your pride has been brought down to Sheol
    along with the music of your harps.
        Maggots are spread out like a bed under you,
            and worms cover you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
How you have fallen from heaven, you morning star, son of the dawn!
    How you have been cut down to the ground, you conqueror of nations!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You thought,
    “I’ll go up to heaven and set up my throne above El’s stars.
    I’ll sit on the mountain far away in the north
        where the gods assemble.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I’ll go above the top of the clouds.
    I’ll be like Elyon.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But you’ve been brought down to Sheol,
    to the deepest part of the pit.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Those who see you stare at you; they look at you closely and say,
    “Is this the man who made the earth tremble,
        who shook the kingdoms,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
who made the world like a desert and tore down its cities,
    who didn’t let his prisoners go home?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
All the kings of the nations, all of them,
    have been buried with honor, each in his own tomb.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But you are thrown out of your tomb like a rejected branch.
    You are covered with those who were killed in battle.
    You go down to the stones of the pit like a trampled corpse.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You won’t be joined by the kings in the tomb,
    because you have destroyed your land and killed your people.
The descendants of the wicked will never be mentioned again.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Prepare a place to slaughter their sons
    because of their ancestors’ guilt.
        They won’t be able to rise, possess the earth,
            and rebuild cities all over it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“I’ll rise up against them,” declares Yahweh Tsebaoth.
    “I’ll cut off the name of the survivors from Babylon,
    its offspring and descendants,” declares Yahweh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“It will become the possession of herons.
    It will become pools of water.
    I’ll sweep it with the broom of destruction,” declares Yahweh Tsebaoth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yahweh Tsebaoth has taken an oath:
    “It will happen exactly as I’ve intended.
    It will turn out exactly as I’ve planned.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I’ll crush Assyria on my land.
    I’ll trample it underfoot on my mountains.
    Then its yoke will be removed from my people,
    and its burden will be removed from their shoulders.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is the plan determined for the whole earth.
    This is how he will use his power against all the nations.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yahweh Tsebaoth has planned it. Who can stop it?
    He is ready to use his power. Who can turn it back?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This was the divine revelation in the year King Ahaz died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
All you Philistines, don’t rejoice
    that the rod of the one who struck you is broken,
        because a viper will come from that snake’s root,
            and his descendant will be a flying, fiery serpent.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The poorest of the poor will eat,
    and the needy will lie down in safety.
        But I will put your root to death with famine
            and kill off your survivors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Cry loudly in the gate!
    Cry out in the city!
        Be frightened, all you Philistines!
    Smoke comes from the north,
    and there are no stragglers in its ranks.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
How should we answer the messengers from the nations?
    Tell them that Yahweh has laid Zion’s foundation,
        and his humble people will find refuge in it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is the divine revelation about Moab.
    In a single night Ar in Moab is laid waste and destroyed!
    In a single night Kir in Moab is laid waste and destroyed!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The people of Dibon go to the temple,
    to the worship sites, to cry.
    Moab wails over Nebo and Medeba.
    Every head is shaved bald, and every beard is cut off.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
In their streets they wear sackcloth.
    On their roofs and in their city squares everyone wails and cries.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Heshbon and Elealeh also cry out.
    Their voices are heard as far away as Jahaz.
    Moab’s armed men cry out.
    Their courage is gone.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My heart cries out for Moab.
    Its people flee as far as Zoar at Eglath Shelishiyah.
        They go up the mountain road to Luhith.
        They cry loudly over the destruction on the way to Horonaim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Nimrim Brook has run dry!
    The grass dries up,
        the vegetation withers,
            and nothing green is left.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
That is why they carry the wealth that they have earned and stored up
    over Willow Ravine.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Cries for help echo throughout the land of Moab.
    Their wailing echoes as far as Eglaim.
    Their wailing echoes as far as Beer Elim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The water in Dimon is red with blood,
    yet I will bring even more on Dimon.
        A lion will attack the fugitives from Moab
            and the survivors from Adamah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Send lambs to the ruler of the land.
    Send lambs from Sela through the desert to my people at Mount Zion.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Moab’s daughters are like fluttering birds,
    like scattered nestlings,
        at the shallow crossings of the Arnon River.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Give us advice.
    Make a decision.
        At high noon make your shadow as dark as night.
            Hide the fugitives.
                Don’t betray the refugees.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Let the fugitives from Moab stay with you a while.
    Be their refuge from the destroyer.
    Ruthless people will come to an end.
    The destruction will end.
        The one who tramples others will be gone.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then Yahweh will set up a trusted king.
    He will rule faithfully.
        He is from the tent of David.
        He judges and searches for justice.
        He is quick to do what is right.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
We’ve heard of the arrogance of Moab’s people.
    They are very arrogant.
    We’ve heard of their boasting, arrogance, and conceit,
    but their boasts aren’t true.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
That is why Moab will wail.
    Everyone will wail for Moab.
    Mourn and grieve over the raisin cakes of Kir Hareseth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The fields of Heshbon and the vineyards of Sibmah wither.
    Rulers of the nations have cut off their grapes.
    The grapevines once reached as far as Jazer
        and strayed out into the desert.
    Their shoots had spread out over the sea.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will cry for the grapevines of Sibmah
    as Jazer cries for them.
        I will drench you with my tears, Heshbon and Elealeh.
    The shouts of joy for your ripened fruits
    and your harvest will be silenced.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Joy and delight have vanished from the orchards.
    No songs are sung.
    No shouts are raised.
    No one stomps on grapes in the winepresses,
        because I have put an end to the shouts of joy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
That is why my heart mourns for Moab like a harp.
    My soul mourns for Kir Hareseth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When the people of Moab appear at the worship site,
    they will only wear themselves out.
    They will come into the holy place to pray,
    but they won’t be able to.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is the message that Yahweh spoke about Moab in the past.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But now Yahweh says, “Moab’s honor will be despised within three years. I will count them like workers count the years left of their contracts. In spite of their great number, the survivors will be very few and powerless.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is the divine revelation about Damascus.
“Damascus will no longer be a city.
    It will become a pile of rubble.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The cities of Aroer will be deserted.
    These cities will be used for sheep, which will lie down in them.
        There will be no one to disturb those sheep.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Fortified cities will disappear from Ephraim,
    and the kingdom will disappear from Damascus.
    The remaining few from Aram will share Israel’s honor,”
    declares Yahweh Tsebaoth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“When that day comes, the honor of Jacob’s people will fade away,
    and they will become skin and bones.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
That time will be like harvesting bundles of grain by the armful.
    It will be like gathering grain in the Rephaim Valley.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Only a few people will survive.
    They will be like an olive tree that has been beaten.
        Only two or three olives are left
            at the top of the highest branch,
                four or five olives on the rest of the branches,”
                    declares Yahweh Elohim of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When that day comes, they will look to their maker,
    and their eyes will look to Qedosh Yisrael.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They won’t look to the altars made by their hands
    or to the Asherah poles or incense altars
        which their fingers molded.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When that day comes, the fortified cities
    which other people abandoned because of the Israelites
        will be like abandoned woods and undergrowth.
    So it will become a wasteland.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You have forgotten the Elohim of your salvation.
    You haven’t remembered the rock, your stronghold.
    Instead, you have planted the best plants
    and have set out the imported grapevines.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
On the day you plant, you will make it grow.
    On the morning you set out the seedling, you will make it sprout.
    But the harvest will become a [rotting] pile
        on a day of grief and incurable pain.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
How horrible it will be for many people!
    They will roar like the roaring sea.
    The noise that the people make
        will be like the noise from rushing water.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The people will make noise like raging water.
    But Elohim will yell at them, and they will run far away.
        They will be chased away
            like husks on the mountains being blown by the wind,
                like whirling dust being blown by a storm.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
In the evening there will be sudden terror.
    Before morning they will be gone.
    This will be the fate of those who looted us,
    the destiny of those who robbed us.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
How horrible it will be for the land of whirring wings
    which lies beyond the rivers of Sudan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
It sends messengers by sea
            in boats made of reeds
                skimming over the surface of the water.
        Go, swift messengers, to a tall and smooth-skinned people,
            a people who are feared far and near,
            a strong and aggressive nation,
                whose land is divided by rivers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Look when someone raises a flag on the mountains.
    Listen when someone blows a ram’s horn,
        all you inhabitants of the world who live on the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is what Yahweh says to me:
I will keep quiet and watch from my dwelling place.
    My presence will be like scorching heat in the sunshine,
        like heavy dew in the heat of the harvest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Before the harvest, when blossoms are gone
    and grapes are ripening from blossoms,
        he will cut off the shoots with pruning shears
            and chop off the spreading branches.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They will be left for the birds of prey on the mountains
    and the wild animals.
        The birds of prey will feed on them in the summer,
            and all the wild animals on earth
                will feed on them in the winter.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
At that time gifts will be brought to Yahweh Tsebaoth
    from a tall and smooth-skinned people,
    a people who are feared far and near,
    a strong and aggressive nation,
        whose land is divided by rivers.
    They will be brought to Mount Zion,
    the place where the name of Yahweh Tsebaoth is.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is the divine revelation about Egypt.
Yahweh is riding on a fast-moving cloud and is coming to Egypt.
    Egypt’s idols will tremble in his presence.
    Egypt’s courage will fail.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“I will turn one Egyptian against another.
    They will fight—
    brother against brother,
    neighbor against neighbor,
    city against city,
    kingdom against kingdom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Egyptians will lose courage.
    I will unravel their plans.
    They will turn to idols, ghosts,
    mediums, and fortunetellers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will hand over the Egyptians to a harsh master.
    A strong king will rule them,”
        declares Adonay Yahweh Tsebaoth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The water in the Nile River will be dried up,
    and the river will be dry and empty.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The canals will stink.
    Egypt’s streams will be emptied and dried up.
    The reeds and cattails will wither.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The rushes by the Nile, by the edge of the Nile,
    and all the fields planted beside the Nile
        will dry up, be blown away, and disappear.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Fishermen will cry.
    All who cast their lines into the Nile will mourn.
        Those who spread their nets on the water will sigh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Linenworkers and weavers will be ashamed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Egypt’s weavers will be crushed.
    Those who work for money will be distressed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The leaders of Zoan are nothing but fools.
    The wisest of Pharaoh’s counselors gives stupid advice.
    How can you tell Pharaoh,
        “I’m a descendant of wise men,
            a descendant of ancient kings”?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Where are your wise men now?
    Let them tell you.
        Let them explain what Yahweh Tsebaoth
            is planning against Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The leaders of Zoan are acting foolishly.
    The leaders of Memphis are led astray.
    The leaders who are the cornerstones of its tribes mislead the Egyptians.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yahweh mixes up their minds.
    So they lead the Egyptians astray
        like a drunk who staggers in his vomit.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
No one—leaders or followers, important or unimportant—
    can do anything for Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At that time Egyptians will act like women. They will tremble and be terrified because Yahweh Tsebaoth will shake his fist at them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The land of Judah will terrify the Egyptians. Whenever they are reminded of Judah, they will be terrified of it because of what Yahweh Tsebaoth is planning against it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When that day comes, five cities in Egypt will have people that speak the language of Canaan and swear allegiance to Yahweh Tsebaoth. One of the cities will be called Heliopolis.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When that day comes, an altar for Yahweh will be in the middle of Egypt, and a stone marker for Yahweh will be near its border.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These objects will be a sign and a witness that Yahweh Tsebaoth is in Egypt. When the people cry to Yahweh because of those who oppress them, he will send a savior and defender to rescue them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Yahweh will make himself known to the Egyptians. The Egyptians will know Yahweh when that day comes. They will worship with sacrifices and food offerings. They will make vows to Yahweh and carry them out.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yahweh will strike Egypt with a plague. When he strikes them, he will also heal them. Then they will come back to Yahweh. And he will respond to their prayers and heal them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When that day comes, a highway will run from Egypt to Assyria. The Assyrians will come to Egypt and the Egyptians to Assyria, and the Egyptians will worship with the Assyrians.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When that day comes, Israel will be one-third of God’s people, along with Egypt and Assyria. They will be a blessing on the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yahweh Tsebaoth will bless them, saying, “My people Egypt, the work of my hands Assyria, and my possession Israel are blessed.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the year when King Sargon of Assyria sent his commander-in-chief to fight against Ashdod, he captured it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At that time Yahweh told Isaiah, son of Amoz, “Take off the sackcloth that you are wearing, and take off your sandals!” Isaiah did this and walked around barefoot and naked.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Yahweh said, “My servant Isaiah has gone barefoot and naked for three years as a sign and as an omen to Egypt and Sudan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king of Assyria will lead away both the young and the old—captives from Egypt and exiles from Sudan. They will be barefoot and naked. Their buttocks will be exposed in order to disgrace Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the people will be shattered and ashamed because Sudan was their hope and Egypt was their beauty.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When that day comes, those who live on this coastland will say, ‘Look at what has happened to our hope. We ran to Egypt for help to be rescued from the king of Assyria. How can we escape?’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is the divine revelation about the desert by the sea.
Like a storm sweeping through the Negev,
    an invader will come from the desert,
        from a terrifying land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I was shown a harsh vision.
    The traitor betrays.
    The destroyer destroys.
        Go to war, Elam!
        Surround them, Media!
    I will put an end to all the groaning.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
That is why my body is full of trembling.
    Pain grips me like the pain of childbirth.
    I’m disturbed by what I hear.
    I’m terrified by what I see.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I’m confused.
    I’m shaking with terror.
    The twilight hours I longed for make me tremble.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Set the table.
    Spread the rugs by the table.
        Eat. Drink.
    Get up, you leaders!
    Prepare your shields for battle!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is what Adonay says to me:
Post a watchman.
    Have him report whatever he sees.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He will see chariots, pairs of horsemen,
    riders on donkeys, and riders on camels.
        Let him watch carefully, very carefully.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The watchman called,
    “Sir, I stand on the watchtower every day.
        Every night, I stand guard at my post.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Look! Here come chariots and horsemen in pairs.”
    Then he said,
    “Babylon has fallen! It has fallen!
        All the idols they worship lie shattered on the ground.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You, my people, have been threshed and winnowed.
    I make known to you what I heard from Yahweh Tsebaoth,
        the Elohim of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is the divine revelation about Dumah.
Someone is calling to me from Seir,
    “Watchman, how much of the night is left?
    Watchman, how much of the night is left?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The watchman answers,
    “Morning is coming, and night will come again.
        If you need to ask, come back and ask.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is the divine revelation about Arabia.
    You caravan of travelers from the people of Dedan
        will spend the night in the forest of Arabia.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Bring water for the thirsty,
    you inhabitants of the land of Tema.
    Bring food to the fugitives.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text: This is what Adonay says to me: All of Kedar’s honor will be gone in another year. I will count it like workers count the years left on their contracts.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The remaining number of archers, Kedar’s mighty archers, will be few. Yahweh Elohim of Israel has spoken.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is the divine revelation about the valley of Vision.
What’s the matter with you?
    Why do all of you go up on the roofs?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You are a city filled with shouting,
    a town filled with noise and excitement.
    Your people weren’t killed with swords.
    Your dead didn’t die in battle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
All your leaders fled together
    and were captured without their bows and arrows.
    All those who were found were taken prisoner
    before any of them could get far away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
That is why I say,
    “Turn away from me
        so that I can cry bitterly.
    Don’t try to comfort me
        because of the destruction brought on my people.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Adonay Yahweh Tsebaoth has chosen a special day.
    It will be a day of confusion and trampling
        in the valley of Vision,
            a day of tearing down walls and crying for help
                in the mountains.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Elam takes its quiver of arrows,
    manned chariots, and horsemen.
    Kir uncovers its shields.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then your fertile valleys will be filled with chariots,
    and horsemen will stand ready in front of the gate.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
On that day Yahweh will remove the defenses of Judah.
You will look for weapons in the House of the Forest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You will see how many places in David’s wall are broken.
    You will store water in the Lower Pool.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You will count the houses in Jerusalem.
    You will tear down those houses in order to fortify the walls.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You will build a reservoir between the two walls
    to hold the water of the Old Pool.
        You didn’t look to Jerusalem’s maker.
        You didn’t see the one who formed it long ago.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
On that day Adonay Yahweh Tsebaoth
    will call for crying and for mourning,
        for shaving your heads and for wearing sackcloth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Instead, you will rejoice, celebrate,
    slaughter cattle, and butcher sheep.
    You will eat meat, drink wine, and say,
    “Let’s eat and drink because tomorrow we’re going to die.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yahweh Tsebaoth revealed this to me: “Certainly, this wrong will not be forgiven even when you die,” says Adonay Yahweh Tsebaoth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is what Adonay Yahweh Tsebaoth says:
Go to Shebna, the man in charge of the palace, and say to him,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“What are you doing here?
    What right do you have to dig a tomb for yourself?
        What right do you have to cut it out in a prominent place?
        What right do you have to carve out
            a resting place for yourself in the rock?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Look, mighty man!
    Yahweh will throw you out.
        He will grab you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He will wrap you up tightly like a turban.
    He will throw you far away into another land.
        There you will die.
            There your splendid chariots will remain.
            There you will become a disgrace to your master’s household.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“I will remove you from your office
    and do away with your position.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When that day comes, I will call my servant Eliakim, son of Hilkiah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will dress him in your linen robe
    and fasten it with your belt.
    I will give him your authority,
    and he will be like a father to those who live in Jerusalem
        and to the nation of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will place the key of the house of David around his neck.
    What he opens no one will shut.
    What he shuts no one will open.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will fasten him firmly in place like a peg,
    and he will be a source of honor for his father’s household.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They will hang on him the whole weight of his father’s household,
    descendants and offspring and all the little utensils,
        from bowls to jars of every kind.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yahweh Tsebaoth declares,
“On that day the peg which I firmly fastened in place will be removed.
    It will be cut off and will fall,
        and everything hanging on it will be destroyed.”
Yahweh has spoken.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is the divine revelation about Tyre.
Cry loudly, you ships of Tarshish!
    Your port at Tyre is destroyed.
        Word has come to the ships from Cyprus.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Be silent, you inhabitants of the coastland, you merchants from Sidon.
    Your messengers have crossed the sea.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The grain of Shihor is on the Mediterranean.
    The harvest of the Nile River is brought to Tyre.
        Tyre became the marketplace for the nations.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Be ashamed, Sidon, because the stronghold by the sea has spoken,
    “I’ve never been in labor or given birth.
        I’ve raised no sons.
        I’ve brought up no daughters.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When the news reaches Egypt,
    the Egyptians will shudder over the news about Tyre.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Travel to Tarshish!
    Cry loudly, you inhabitants of the seacoast!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Is this your bustling city founded in the distant past?
    Is this the city that sent its people to settle in distant lands?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Who planned such a thing against Tyre, the city that produced kings?
    Its merchants are princes.
        Its traders are among the honored people of the world.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yahweh Tsebaoth planned this
    in order to dishonor all arrogant people
        and to humiliate all the honored people of the world.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Travel through your country like the Nile, people of Tarshish.
    You no longer have a harbor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yahweh has stretched his hand over the sea to shake kingdoms.
    He has commanded that Canaan’s fortifications be destroyed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He says, “You will no longer be joyful,
    my dear abused people Sidon.”
    Get up, and travel to Cyprus.
    Even there you will find no rest.
verses.speaker: Narrator
