verses.text:
Look at the land of the Babylonians.
    These people will be gone.
    Assyria gave this land to the desert animals.
    Assyria set up battle towers,
        stripped palaces bare,
            and turned these places into ruins.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Cry loudly, you ships of Tarshish, because your fortress will be destroyed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When that day comes, Tyre will be forgotten for 70 years, the lifetime of one king. At the end of the 70 years, Tyre will be like the prostitute in this song:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Take your lyre.
    Go around in the city, you forgotten prostitute.
    Make sweet music.
    Sing many songs so that you’ll be remembered.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At the end of 70 years Yahweh will come to help Tyre. Then she will go back to earning money as a prostitute. She will become a prostitute for all the world’s kingdoms.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Her profits and her earnings will be turned over to Yahweh for his holy purpose. It won’t be stored or hoarded. Her merchandise will belong to those who live in the presence of Yahweh so that they will have plenty of food and expensive clothing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yahweh is going to turn the earth into a desolate wasteland.
    He will mar the face of the earth and scatter the people living on it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The same will happen to people and priests,
    male slaves and masters,
        female slaves and masters,
        buyers and sellers,
        lenders and borrowers,
        debtors and creditors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The earth will be completely laid waste and stripped
    because Yahweh has spoken.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The earth dries up and withers.
    The world wastes away and withers.
    The great leaders of the earth waste away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The earth is polluted by those who live on it
    because they’ve disobeyed the Lord’s teachings,
        violated his laws,
            and rejected the everlasting promise.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
That is why a curse devours the earth,
    and its people are punished for their guilt.
    That is why those who live on the earth are burned up,
    and only a few people are left.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
New wine dries up, and grapevines waste away.
    All happy people groan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Joyful tambourine music stops.
    Noisy celebrations cease.
        Joyful harp music stops.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
People no longer drink wine when they sing.
    Liquor tastes bad to its drinkers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The ruined city lies desolate.
    The entrance to every house is barred shut.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
People in the streets call for wine.
    All joy passes away,
    and the earth’s happiness is banished.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The city is left in ruins.
    Its gate is battered to pieces.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
That is the way it will be on earth among the nations.
    They will be like an olive tree which has been shaken
        or like what’s left after the grape harvest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They raise their voices.
    They shout for joy.
        From the sea they sing joyfully about Yahweh’s majesty.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Honor Yahweh in the east.
    Honor the name of Yahweh Elohim of Israel along the coastlands.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
From the ends of the earth we hear songs of praise
    that honor the Righteous One.
But I kept saying,
    “I’m wasting away! I’m wasting away!
        How horrible it is for me!
            Traitors continue to betray,
                and their treachery grows worse and worse.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Disasters, pits, and traps
    are in store for those who live on earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Whoever flees from news of a disaster will fall into a pit.
    Whoever climbs out of that pit will be caught in a trap.
    The floodgates in the sky will be opened,
    and the foundations of the earth will shake.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The earth will be completely broken.
    The earth will shake back and forth violently.
    The earth will stagger.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The earth will stumble like a drunk
    and sway like a shack in the wind.
    Its disobedience weighs heavy on it.
    It will fall and not get up again.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
On that day Yahweh will punish heaven’s armies in heaven
    and earth’s kings on earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They’ll be gathered like prisoners in a jail
    and locked in prison.
        After a long time they’ll be punished.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The moon will be embarrassed.
    The sun will be ashamed,
        because Yahweh Tsebaoth will rule
            on Mount Zion and in Jerusalem.
                He will be glorious
    in the presence of his respected leaders.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
O Yahweh, you are my Elohim.
    I will highly honor you; I will praise your name.
    You have done miraculous things.
    You have been completely reliable
        in carrying out your plans from long ago.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You have turned cities into ruins,
    fortified cities into piles of rubble,
        and foreigners’ palaces into cities that will never be rebuilt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
That is why strong people will honor you,
    and cities ruled by the world’s tyrants will fear you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You have been a refuge for the poor,
    a refuge for the needy in their distress,
    a shelter from the rain, and shade from the heat.
    (A tyrant’s breath is like a rainstorm against a wall,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
like heat in a dry land.)
    You calm the uproar of foreigners.
    The song of tyrants is silenced
        like heat that is reduced by the shadow of a cloud.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
On this mountain Yahweh Tsebaoth will prepare for all people
    a feast with the best foods,
    a banquet with aged wines,
        with the best foods and the finest wines.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
On this mountain he will remove
    the veil of grief covering all people
        and the mask covering all nations.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He will swallow up death forever.
    Adonay Yahweh will wipe away tears from every face,
    and he will remove the disgrace of his people from the whole earth.
        Yahweh has spoken.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
On that day his people will say,
    “This is our Elohim; we have waited for him, and now he will save us.
    This is Yahweh; we have waited for him.
        Let us rejoice and be glad because he will save us.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yahweh’s power will be on this mountain.
    Moab will be trampled beneath him
        like straw that is trampled in a pile of manure.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Moabites will stretch out their hands in the manure
    like swimmers who stretch out their hands to swim.
    The Lord will humble those arrogant people
        despite the movements of their hands.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He will bring down Moab’s high fortified walls,
    level them, and throw them into the dust on the ground.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
On that day this song will be sung in the land of Judah:
We have a strong city.
    Its walls and fortifications provide safety.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Open the gates, and let the righteous nation come in,
    the nation that remains faithful.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
With perfect peace you will protect those whose minds cannot be changed,
    because they trust you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Trust Yahweh always,
    because Yah, Yahweh alone, is an everlasting rock.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He has brought down those who live high in the towering city.
    He levels it.
    He levels it to the ground and throws it into the dust.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Feet trample it,
    the feet of the oppressed,
        the footsteps of the poor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The path of the righteous is level.
    O Upright One, you make the road of the righteous smooth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Certainly, we wait with hope for you, O Yahweh,
    as we follow the path of your guiding principles.
        We want to remember you and your name.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
With my soul I long for you at night.
    Yes, with my spirit I eagerly look for you.
    When your guiding principles are on earth,
    those who live in the world learn to do what is right.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Although the wicked are shown pity,
    they do not learn to do what is right.
    They do what is wrong in the upright land
        and do not see the majesty of Yahweh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
O Yahweh, your power is visible, but they do not see it.
    They will see how devoted your people are,
        and they will be put to shame.
    Your burning anger will destroy your enemies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
O Yahweh, you will establish peace for us,
    since you have done everything for us.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
O Yahweh, our Elohim, you are not the only master to rule us,
    but we acknowledge only you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The wicked are dead.
    They are no longer alive.
        The spirits of the dead won’t rise.
    You have punished them, destroyed them,
    and wiped out all memory of them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You have expanded the nation, O Yahweh.
    You have expanded the nation.
    You are honored.
    You have extended all the land’s boundaries.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
O Yahweh, the people have come to you in trouble.
    They were humbled by oppression, by your discipline upon them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
O Yahweh, when we are with you,
    we are like pregnant women ready to give birth.
        They writhe and cry out in their labor pains.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
We were pregnant; we writhed with labor pains
    only to give birth to the wind.
    We weren’t able to bring salvation to the land,
        and no new people were born on earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your dead will live.
    Their corpses will rise.
    Those who lie dead in the dust will wake up and shout for joy,
    because your dew is a refreshing dew,
        and the earth will revive the spirits of the dead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My people, go to your rooms,
    and shut the doors behind you.
    Hide for a little while until his fury has ended.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yahweh is going to come out from his dwelling place
    to punish those who live on earth for their sins.
        The earth will uncover the blood shed on it
            and will no longer cover up its dead bodies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
On that day Yahweh will use his fierce and powerful sword
    to punish Leviathan, that slippery snake,
        Leviathan, that twisting snake.
            He will kill that monster which lives in the sea.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On that day sing about a delightful vineyard.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I, Yahweh, watch over it.
    I water it continually.
    I watch over it day and night
        so that no one will harm it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I am no longer angry.
    If only thorns and briars would confront me!
        I would fight them in battle and set all of them on fire.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Or else let them come to me for protection.
    Let them make peace with me.
        Yes, let them make peace with me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
In times to come Jacob will take root.
    Israel will blossom, bud,
        and fill the whole world with fruit.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Will Yahweh hurt Israel as he hurt others who hurt them?
    Will he kill them as he killed others?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He punished Israel by sending it away.
    He removed it with a fierce blast from the east winds.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
In this way the wrongdoings of the descendants of Jacob are covered up.
    This is the way they will turn from their sins—
    when they turn all the altar stones into powdered chalk
        and no poles dedicated to the goddess Asherah
            or incense altars are left standing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The fortified city is isolated.
    The homestead is left deserted, abandoned like the desert.
    Calves will graze there.
    They will lie down.
        They will feed on the branches.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When the branches are dried up,
    they will be broken off.
    Women will come and build a fire with them.
    These people don’t understand these things.
        That is why their maker won’t have compassion on them,
            and their Creator won’t have pity on them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
On that day Yahweh will begin his threshing
    from the flowing stream of the Euphrates River
        to the brook of Egypt.
    People of Israel, you will be gathered one by one.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
On that day a ram’s horn will be blown loudly.
    Those who are dying in Assyria
        and those who are banished to Egypt
            will come and worship Yahweh
                on the holy mountain in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
How horrible it will be for the arrogant drunks of Ephraim.
    Their glorious beauty is like a withered flower.
        They are at the entrance to a fertile valley
            where they lie drunk from wine.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Adonay has one who is strong and powerful.
    He is like a hailstorm, a destructive wind.
    He is like a thunderstorm, an overwhelming flood.
        He will throw them to the ground forcefully.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The arrogant drunks of Ephraim will be trampled underfoot.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Their glorious beauty is like a withered flower.
    They are at the entrance to a fertile valley.
        They will be like figs that ripened early.
            As soon as someone sees them,
                they will be taken and eaten.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When that day comes, Yahweh Tsebaoth will be
    like a glorious crown for his few remaining people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He will give a spirit of justice to those who judge.
    He will give strength to those who defend the city gates in battle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Priests and prophets stagger from wine and wobble from too much liquor.
    They stagger from too much liquor
        and become confused from too much wine.
    They wobble because of their liquor.
    They stagger when they see visions.
    They swerve as they judge.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
All the tables are covered with vomit and excrement.
    There isn’t a clean place left.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
To whom will they make the message understood?
    To whom will they explain this message?
    To children just weaned from milk?
    To those just taken from their mother’s breasts?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They speak utter nonsense.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yahweh will speak to these people.
    He will mock them by speaking in a foreign language.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He will say to them,
    “This is a place for comfort.
        This is a place of rest for those who are tired.
            This is a place for them to rest.”
    But they weren’t willing to listen.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yahweh speaks utter nonsense to them.
    That is why they will fall backwards.
    That is why they will be hurt, trapped, and captured.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So hear the word of Yahweh, you foolish talkers
    who rule the people in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You say, “We made a treaty with death
    and an agreement with the grave.
    When the overwhelming disaster passes by,
    it won’t matter to us,
        because we have taken refuge in our lies,
            and falsehood is our hiding place.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is what Adonay Yahweh says:
I am going to lay a rock in Zion,
    a rock that has been tested,
    a precious cornerstone,
    a solid foundation.
        Whoever believes in him will not worry.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will make justice a measuring line
    and righteousness a plumb line.
    Hail will sweep away your refuge of lies,
    and floodwaters will wash away your hiding place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your treaty with death will be wiped away.
    Your agreement with the grave will not stand.
    When the overwhelming disaster passes by,
    you will be trampled by it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Each time it passes by it will take you.
    It will pass by morning after morning,
        during the day and during the night.
            Understanding this message brings only terror.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The bed is too short to stretch out on.
    The blanket is too narrow to serve as a cover.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yahweh will rise as he did on Mount Perazim.
    He will wake up as he did in Gibeon Valley.
    He will do his work, his unexpected work,
        and perform his deeds, his mysterious deeds.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Now stop laughing, or your chains will be tightened,
    because I have heard that Adonay Yahweh Tsebaoth
        has finally determined to destroy the whole land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Open your ears, and listen to me!
    Pay attention, and hear me!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Does a farmer go on plowing every day so he can plant?
    Does he continue to break up the soil and make furrows in the ground?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When he has smoothed its surface,
    doesn’t he scatter black cumin seed and plant cumin?
        Doesn’t he plant wild wheat in rows?
        Doesn’t he put barley in its own area
            and winter wheat at its borders?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yahweh will guide him in judgment,
    and his Elohim will teach him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Black cumin isn’t threshed with a sledge,
    and wagon wheels aren’t rolled over cumin.
    Black cumin is beaten with a rod
    and cumin with a stick.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Grain is ground into flour, but the grinding eventually stops.
    It will be threshed.
    The wheels of his cart will roll over it,
        but his horses won’t crush it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
All of this has come from Yahweh Tsebaoth.
    His counsel is wonderful, and his wisdom is great.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
How horrible it will be for you Ariel, Ariel,
    the city where David camped.
        Let year after year go by.
        Let your annual festivals go on.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will torment Ariel,
    and the city will be filled with people grieving and mourning.
        The city will become like Ariel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will set up war camps all around you.
    I will blockade you with towers.
    I will put up mounds of dirt around you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When you have fallen, you will speak as you lie on the ground.
    Your words will be muffled by the dust.
    Your voice will come out of the ground like that of a ghost.
    Your words will be whispered from the dust.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your many enemies will be like fine dust.
    Your many foes will be like husks blown by the wind.
    All of this will happen suddenly, unexpectedly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yahweh Tsebaoth will punish you
    with thunder, earthquakes, and loud noises,
    with windstorms, rainstorms, and fire storms.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The armies from all the nations will go to war against Ariel.
    They will go to war against it, blockade it, and torment it.
    All of this will be like a dream, like a vision in the night.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They will be like hungry people who dream that they’re eating
    and wake up to find they’re hungry.
    They will be like thirsty people who dream that they’re drinking
    and wake up to find they’re lightheaded and parched with thirst.
    This is what will happen to the armies from all the nations
    that fight against Mount Zion.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If you confuse yourselves, you will be confused.
    If you blind yourselves, you will be blinded.
    You are drunk, but not from wine.
    You stagger, but not from liquor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yahweh has poured out on you a spirit of deep sleep.
    He will shut your eyes. (Your eyes are the prophets.)
    He will cover your heads. (Your heads are the seers.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
To you all these visions will be like words in a book that is closed and sealed. You give this book to someone who can read, saying, “Please read this.”
He answers, “I can’t read it. It’s sealed.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then you give the book to someone who can’t read, saying, “Please read this.”
He answers, “I can’t read.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Adonay says,
“These people worship me with their mouths
    and honor me with their lips.
        But their hearts are far from me,
            and their worship of me is based on rules made by humans.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
That is why I am going to do something completely amazing
    for these people once again.
        The wisdom of their wise people will disappear.
        The intelligence of their intelligent people will be hidden.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
How horrible it will be for those
    who try to hide their plans from Yahweh.
        Their deeds are done in the dark,
            and they say, “No one can see us”
                and “No one can recognize us.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You turn things upside down!
    Is the potter no better than his clay?
    Can something that has been made
        say about its maker, “He didn’t make me”?
    Can a piece of pottery
        say about the potter, “He doesn’t understand”?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
In a very short time Lebanon will be turned into a fertile field
    and the fertile field will be considered a forest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When that day comes, the deaf will hear the words written in the book.
    The blind will see out of their gloom and darkness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Humble people again will find joy in Yahweh.
    The poorest of people will find joy in Qedosh Yisrael.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Tyrants will be gone.
    Mockers will be finished.
    All who look for ways to do wrong will come to an end:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
those who make people sin with words,
    those who lay traps for judges,
        those who, without any reason, deny justice
            to people who are in the right.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is what Yahweh, who saved Abraham, says about the descendants of Jacob:
Jacob will no longer be ashamed.
    Jacob’s face will no longer turn pale.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When they see all their children,
    the children I made with my hands,
        they will acknowledge my name as holy.
            They will treat the Holy One of Jacob as holy.
            They will stand in terror of the Elohim of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then those who are wayward in spirit will gain understanding,
    and those who complain will accept instruction.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yahweh declares,
“How horrible it will be for those rebellious children.
    They carry out plans, but not mine.
    They make alliances against my will.
    They pile sin on top of sin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They go to Egypt without asking me.
    They look for shelter under Pharaoh’s protection
        and look for refuge in Egypt’s shadow.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But Pharaoh’s protection will be their shame,
    and the refuge in Egypt’s shadow will be their disgrace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Although Pharaoh’s officials are in Zoan
    and his messengers have reached Hanes,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
the people of Judah will be put to shame
            because that nation can’t help them.
                That nation can’t give aid or help to them.
                It can only offer shame and disgrace.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is the divine revelation about the animals in the Negev.
“My people travel through lands
    where they experience distress and hardship.
        Lions and lionesses live there.
        Vipers and poisonous snakes live there.
    They carry their riches on the backs of young donkeys
    and their treasures on the humps of camels
        to a nation that can’t help them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Egypt’s help is completely useless.
    That is why I call it, ‘Rahab who sits still.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Now, write this on a tablet for them, and inscribe it in a book
    so that it will be there in the future as a permanent witness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
These people are rebellious and deceitful children,
    children who refuse to listen to Yahweh’s teachings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They say to the seers, ‘Don’t see the future.’
    They say to those who have visions,
    ‘Don’t have visions that tell us what is right.
    Tell us what we want to hear. See illusions.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Get out of our way! Stop blocking our path!
    Get Qedosh Yisrael out of our sight.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is what Qedosh Yisrael says:
You have rejected this warning,
    trusted oppression and deceit,
        and leaned on them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
That is why your sin will be
    like a high wall with a bulging crack, ready to fall.
        All of a sudden it will fall.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
It will break like pottery.
    It will be smashed, and nothing will be left of it.
    No piece will be big enough to carry live coals from a fireplace
        or to dip water from a reservoir.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is what Adonay Yahweh, Qedosh Yisrael, says:
You can be saved by returning to me.
    You can have rest.
    You can be strong by being quiet and by trusting me.
    But you don’t want that.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You’ve said, “No, we’ll flee on horses.”
    So you flee.
    You’ve added, “We’ll ride on fast horses.”
        So those who chase you will also be fast.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
One thousand people will flee when one person threatens them,
    and you will flee when five threaten you.
        Then you will be left alone
            like a flagpole on top of a mountain,
            like a signpost on a hill.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yahweh is waiting to be kind to you.
    He rises to have compassion on you.
    Yahweh is an Elohim of justice.
        Blessed are all those who wait for him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You will live in Zion, in Jerusalem. You won’t cry anymore. Yahweh will certainly have pity on you when you cry for help. As soon as he hears you, he will answer you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Adonay may give you troubles and hardships. But your teacher will no longer be hidden from you. You will see your teacher with your own eyes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You will hear a voice behind you saying, “This is the way. Follow it, whether it turns to the right or to the left.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then you will dishonor your silver-plated idols and your gold-covered statues. You will throw them away like clothing ruined by stains. You will say to them, “Get out!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Adonay will give you rain for the seed that you plant in the ground, and the food that the ground provides will be rich and nourishing. When that day comes, your cattle will graze in large pastures.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The oxen and the donkeys which work the soil will eat a mixture of food that has been winnowed with forks and shovels.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There will be brooks and streams on every lofty mountain and every high hill. When the day of the great slaughter comes, towers will fall.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the light of the moon will be like the light of the sun. The light of the sun will be seven times as strong, like the light of seven days. When that day comes, Yahweh will bandage his people’s injuries and heal the wounds he inflicted.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The name of Yahweh is going to come from far away.
    His anger is burning.
    His burden is heavy.
    His lips are filled with fury.
    His tongue is like a devouring flame.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
His breath is like an overflowing stream.
    It rises neck high,
        sifting the nations with a sieve of destruction,
            placing a bit in the mouths of the people
                to lead them astray.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You will sing a song
    like the song you sing on a festival night.
    Your hearts will be happy like someone going out with a flute
    on the way to Yahweh’s mountain, to the rock of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yahweh will make his majestic voice heard.
    He will come down with all his might,
    with furious anger,
    with fire storms, windstorms, rainstorms, and hailstones.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
At the sound of Yahweh, the people of Assyria will be shattered.
    He will strike them with his rod.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
To the sound of tambourines and lyres, Yahweh will pound on them.
    He will fight them in battle, swinging his fists.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Topheth was prepared long ago.
    It was made ready for the king.
    It was made deep and wide and piled high with plenty of burning logs.
    Yahweh’s breath will be like a flood of burning sulfur,
    setting it on fire.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
How horrible it will be for those
    who go to Egypt for help,
    who rely on horses,
    who depend on many chariots,
    who depend on very strong war horses.
        They don’t look to Qedosh Yisrael.
        They don’t seek Yahweh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He is wise and can bring about disaster.
            He doesn’t take back his words.
            He rises against wicked people
                and against those who help troublemakers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Egyptians are humans, not gods.
    Their horses are flesh and blood, not spirit.
    When Yahweh uses his powerful hand,
    the one who gives help will stumble,
        and the one who receives help will fall.
            Both will die together.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is what Yahweh said to me:
A lion, even a young lion, growls over its prey
    when a crowd of shepherds is called to fight it.
        It isn’t frightened by their voices
            or disturbed by the noise they make.
    So Yahweh Tsebaoth will come to fight for
    Mount Zion and its hill.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yahweh Tsebaoth will defend Jerusalem like a hovering bird.
    He will defend it and rescue it.
    He will pass over it and protect it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You people of Israel, return to the one
    whom you have so violently rebelled against.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When that day comes, all of you will reject
    the silver and gold idols
        that your sinful hands have made.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then Assyrians will be killed with swords not made by human hands.
    Swords not made by human hands will destroy them.
    They will flee from battle,
    and their young men will be made to do forced labor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
In terror they will run to their stronghold,
    and their officers will be frightened at the sight of the battle flag.
Yahweh declares this. His fire is in Zion and his furnace is in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A king will rule with fairness,
    and officials will rule with justice.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then each ruler will be like a shelter from the wind
    and a hiding place from the rain.
    They will be like streams on parched ground
    and the shade of a large rock in a weary land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then the vision of those who can see won’t be blurred,
    and the ears of those who can hear will pay attention.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then those who are reckless will begin to understand,
    and those who stutter will speak quickly and clearly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Godless fools will no longer be called nobles,
    nor will scoundrels be considered gentlemen.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Godless fools speak foolishness,
    and their minds plan evil
        in order to do ungodly things.
    They speak falsely about Yahweh.
    They let people go hungry
    and withhold water from thirsty people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The tricks of scoundrels are evil.
    They devise wicked plans in order to ruin poor people with lies,
        even when needy people plead for justice.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But honorable people act honorably
    and stand firm for what is honorable.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Get up, and listen to me, you pampered women.
    Hear what I say, you overconfident daughters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
In a little less than a year
    you overconfident women will tremble,
        because the grape harvest will fail
            and no fruit will be brought in from the fields.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Shudder, you pampered women.
    Tremble, you overconfident women.
    Take off your clothes, walk around naked,
    and wear sackcloth around your waists.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Beat your breasts as you mourn for the fields,
    for the vines bearing grapes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Mourn for my people’s land where thorns and briars will grow.
    Mourn for all the happy homes in a joyful city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Palaces will be deserted.
    Noisy cities will be abandoned.
    Fortresses and watchtowers will become permanent caves.
    They will be a delight for wild donkeys and pastures for flocks
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
until the Ruach is poured on us from on high.
    Then the wilderness will be turned into a fertile field,
    and the fertile field will be considered a forest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then justice will live in the wilderness,
    and righteousness will be at home in the fertile field.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then an act of righteousness will bring about peace,
    calm, and safety forever.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My people will live in a peaceful place,
    in safe homes and quiet places of rest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The forest will be flattened because of hail,
    and the city will be completely leveled.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Blessed are those who plant beside every stream
    and those who let oxen and donkeys roam freely.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
How horrible it will be for you, you destroyer,
    although you haven’t been destroyed.
    How horrible it will be for you, you traitor,
    although you haven’t been betrayed.
    When you’ve finished destroying, you will be destroyed.
    When you’ve finished being a traitor, you will be betrayed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
O Yahweh, have pity on us.
    We wait with hope for you.
    Be our strength in the morning.
    Yes, be our savior in times of trouble.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
People flee from the noise of your army.
    Nations scatter when you attack.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You nations, your loot is gathered as grasshoppers harvest a crop.
    Like swarming locusts, people rush for your loot.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yahweh is honored because he lives on high.
    He will fill Zion with justice and righteousness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He will be the foundation of your future.
    The riches of salvation are wisdom and knowledge.
    The fear of Yahweh is your treasure.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Heroes cry in the streets.
    Messengers of peace cry bitterly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Highways are deserted.
    Travelers stop traveling.
    Agreements are broken.
    Witnesses are rejected.
    People are no longer respected.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The country grieves and wastes away.
    Lebanon is ashamed and is decaying.
    Sharon has become like a wilderness.
    Bashan and Carmel are shaken.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yahweh says, “Now I will arise.
    Now I will get up.
    Now I will be lifted up.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You will be pregnant with hay.
    You will give birth to straw.
    Your breath will be a fire which will burn you up.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
People will be cremated.
    They will be set on fire like dry thornbushes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Hear what I have done, you people who are far away!
    Acknowledge my might, you people who are near!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The sinners in Zion are terrified.
    Trembling seizes the ungodly.
    Can any of us live through a fire that destroys?
    Can any of us live through a fire that burns forever?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The person who does what is right and speaks the truth will live.
    He rejects getting rich by extortion and refuses to take bribes.
        He refuses to listen to those who are plotting murders.
        He doesn’t look for evil things to do.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This person will live on high.
    His stronghold will be a fortress made of rock.
        He will have plenty of food
            and a dependable supply of water.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your eyes will see how handsome the king is.
    You will see a land that stretches into the distance.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your mind will be thinking of the terrors in the past.
    Where are the scribes?
    Where are the tax collectors?
    Where are those who counted the towers?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You will no longer see those savage people,
    those people with an unrecognizable language,
        with a foreign language that you can’t understand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Look at Zion, the city of our festivals.
    Your eyes will see Jerusalem as a peaceful place.
    It is a tent that can’t be moved.
        Its tent pegs will never be pulled out,
            and none of its ropes will be broken.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yahweh will be our mighty defender
    in a place surrounded by wide rivers and streams.
        Ships with oars won’t travel on them.
        Stately ships won’t sail on them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yahweh is our Shophet.
    Yahweh is our lawgiver.
    Yahweh is our Melek.
    Yahweh is our savior.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your ropes hang loose,
    your mast isn’t secure,
        and your sail isn’t spread out.
    A large amount of loot will be distributed.
    Lame people will carry off your loot.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
No one who lives in Zion will say, “I’m sick.”
    The sins of its inhabitants will be forgiven.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Come close, you nations, and listen.
    Pay attention, you people.
    The earth, everyone in it,
    the world, and everything on it will listen.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yahweh is angry with all the nations.
    He is furious with all their armies.
    He has claimed them for destruction.
    He has handed them over to be slaughtered.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Their dead bodies will be thrown out.
            A stench will rise from their corpses.
                Mountains will be red with their blood.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
All the stars in the sky will rot.
    The heavens will be rolled up like a scroll.
    The stars will fall
    like leaves from a grapevine,
    like green figs from a fig tree.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When my sword is covered with blood in the heavens,
    it will fall on Edom
        and on the people I’ve claimed for destruction.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yahweh’s sword is covered with blood.
    It is covered with fat,
        with the blood of lambs and goats,
        with the fat of rams’ kidneys.
    Yahweh will receive a sacrifice in Bozrah,
    a huge slaughter in the land of Edom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Wild oxen will be killed with them,
    young bulls along with rams.
    Their land will be drenched with blood.
    Their dust will be covered with fat.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yahweh will have a day of vengeance,
    a year of revenge in defense of Zion.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Edom’s streams will be turned to tar.
    Its soil will be turned to burning sulfur.
    Its land will become blazing tar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They will not be extinguished day or night,
    and smoke will always go up from them.
    Edom will lie in ruins for generations.
    No one will ever travel through it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Pelicans and herons will take possession of the land.
    Owls and crows will live there.
    He will stretch the measuring line of chaos
    and the plumb line of destruction over it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
There are no nobles to rule a kingdom.
    All of its princes have disappeared.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Its palaces are covered with thorns.
    Its fortresses have nettles and thistles.
    It will become a home for jackals
        and a place for ostriches.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Hyenas will meet with jackals.
    Male goats will call to their mates.
        Screech owls will rest there
            and find a resting place for themselves.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Owls will make their nests there, lay eggs, and hatch them.
    They will gather their young
        in the shadow of their wings.
            Vultures also will gather there,
                each one with its mate.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Search Yahweh’s book, and read it.
    Not one of these animals will be missing.
    Not one will lack a mate,
        because Yahweh has commanded it,
            and his Ruach will gather them together.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He is the one who throws dice for them,
    and his hand divides up the land for them with a measuring line.
    They will possess it permanently
    and live there for generations.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The desert and the dry land will be glad,
    and the wilderness will rejoice and blossom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Like a lily the land will blossom.
    It will rejoice and sing with joy.
    It will have the glory of Lebanon, the majesty of Carmel and Sharon.
    Everyone will see the glory of Yahweh, the majesty of our Elohim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Strengthen limp hands.
    Steady weak knees.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Tell those who are terrified,
    “Be brave; don’t be afraid.
        Your Elohim will come with vengeance, with divine revenge.
            He will come and rescue you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then the eyes of the blind will be opened,
    and the ears of the deaf will be unplugged.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then those who are lame will leap like deer,
    and those who cannot speak will shout for joy.
    Water will gush out into the desert,
    and streams will gush out into the wilderness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then the hot sand will become a pool,
    and dry ground will have springs.
    Grass will become cattails and rushes
    in the home of jackals.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A highway will be there, a roadway.
    It will be called the Holy Road.
        Sinners won’t travel on it.
    It will be for those who walk on it.
        Godless fools won’t wander onto it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Lions won’t be there.
        Wild animals won’t go on it.
            They won’t be found there.
    But the people reclaimed by the Lord will walk on it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The people ransomed by Yahweh will return.
    They will come to Zion singing with joy.
        Everlasting happiness will be on their heads as a crown.
            They will be glad and joyful.
                They will have no sorrow or grief.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In Hezekiah’s fourteenth year as king, King Sennacherib of Assyria attacked all the fortified cities of Judah and captured them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king of Assyria sent his field commander with a large army from Lachish to King Hezekiah at Jerusalem. He stood at the channel for the Upper Pool on the road to Laundryman’s Field.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Eliakim, who was in charge of the palace and was the son of Hilkiah, Shebna the scribe, and Joah, who was the royal historian and the son of Asaph, went out to the field commander.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The field commander said to them, “Tell Hezekiah, ‘This is what the great king, the king of Assyria, says: What makes you so confident?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You give useless advice about getting ready for war. Whom, then, do you trust for support in your rebellion against me?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Look! When you trust Egypt, you’re trusting a broken stick for a staff. If you lean on it, it stabs your hand and goes through it. This is what Pharaoh (the king of Egypt) is like for everyone who trusts him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Suppose you tell me, “We’re trusting Yahweh our Elohim.” He’s the god whose places of worship and altars Hezekiah got rid of. Hezekiah told Judah and Jerusalem, “Worship at this altar.”’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Now, make a deal with my master, the king of Assyria. I’ll give you 2,000 horses if you can put riders on them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: How can you defeat my master’s lowest-ranking officers when you trust Egypt for chariots and horses?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Have I come to destroy this country without Yahweh on my side? Yahweh said to me, ‘Attack this country, and destroy it.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Eliakim, Shebna, and Joah said to the field commander, “Speak to us in Aramaic, since we understand it. Don’t speak to us in the Judean language as long as there are people on the wall listening.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the field commander asked, “Did my master send me to tell these things only to you and your master? Didn’t he send me to the men sitting on the wall who will have to eat their own excrement and drink their own urine with you?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the field commander stood and shouted loudly in the Judean language, “Listen to the great king, the king of Assyria.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what the king says: Don’t let Hezekiah deceive you. He can’t rescue you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Don’t let Hezekiah get you to trust Yahweh by saying, ‘Yahweh will certainly rescue us, and this city will not be put under the control of the king of Assyria.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Don’t listen to Hezekiah, because this is what the king of Assyria says: Make peace with me! Come out, and give yourselves up to me! Everyone will eat from his own grapevine and fig tree and drink from his own cistern.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then I will come and take you away to a country like your own. It’s a country with grain and new wine, a country with bread and vineyards.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Don’t let Hezekiah mislead you by saying to you, ‘Yahweh will rescue us.’ Did any of the gods of the nations rescue their countries from the king of Assyria?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Where are the gods of Hamath and Arpad? Where are the gods of Sepharvaim? Did they rescue Samaria from my control?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Did the gods of these countries rescue them from my control? Could Yahweh then rescue Jerusalem from my control?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They were silent and didn’t say anything to him because the king commanded them not to answer him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Eliakim, who was in charge of the palace and was son of Hilkiah, Shebna the scribe, and Joah, who was the royal historian and the son of Asaph, went to Hezekiah with their clothes torn in grief. They told him the message from the field commander.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When King Hezekiah heard the message, he tore his clothes in grief, covered himself with sackcloth, and went into Yahweh’s temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he sent Eliakim, who was in charge of the palace, Shebna the scribe, and the leaders of the priests, clothed in sackcloth, to the prophet Isaiah, son of Amoz.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They said to him, “This is what Hezekiah says: Today is a day filled with misery, punishment, and disgrace. We are like a woman who is about to give birth but doesn’t have the strength to do it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yahweh your Elohim may have heard the words of the field commander. His master, the king of Assyria, sent him to defy Elohim Chay. Yahweh your Elohim may punish him because of the message that Yahweh your Elohim heard. Pray for the few people who are left.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So King Hezekiah’s men went to Isaiah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Isaiah answered them, “Say this to your master, ‘This is what Yahweh says: Don’t be afraid of the message that you heard when the Assyrian king’s assistants slandered me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I’m going to put a spirit in him so that he will hear a rumor and return to his own country. I’ll have him assassinated in his own country.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The field commander returned and found the king of Assyria fighting against Libnah. He had heard that the king left Lachish.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Now, Sennacherib heard that King Tirhakah of Sudan was coming to fight him.
When he heard this, he again sent messengers to Hezekiah, saying,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Tell King Hezekiah of Judah, ‘Don’t let the god whom you trust deceive you by saying that Jerusalem will not be put under the control of the king of Assyria.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You heard what the kings of Assyria did to all countries, how they totally destroyed them. Will you be rescued?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Did the gods of the nations which my ancestors destroyed rescue Gozan, Haran, Rezeph, and the people of Eden who were in Telassar?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Where is the king of Hamath, the king of Arpad, and the king of the cities of Sepharvaim, Hena, and Ivvah?’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hezekiah took the letter from the messengers, read it, and went to Yahweh’s temple. He spread it out in front of Yahweh
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and prayed to Yahweh,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Yahweh Tsebaoth, Elohim of Israel, you are enthroned over the angels. You alone are Elohim of the kingdoms of the world. You made heaven and earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Turn your ear toward me, Yahweh, and listen. Open your eyes, Yahweh, and see. Listen to the entire message that Sennacherib sent to defy Elohim Chay.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It is true, Yahweh, that the kings of Assyria have leveled every country.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They have thrown the gods from these countries into fires because these gods aren’t real gods. They’re only wooden and stone statues made by human hands. So the Assyrians have destroyed them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now, Yahweh our Elohim, rescue us from Assyria’s control so that all the kingdoms on earth will know that you alone are Yahweh.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Isaiah, son of Amoz, sent a message to Hezekiah, “This is what Yahweh Elohim of Israel says: You prayed to me about King Sennacherib of Assyria.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is the message that Yahweh speaks to him,
‘My dear people in Zion despise you and laugh at you.
    My people in Jerusalem shake their heads behind your back.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Whom are you defying and slandering?
    Against whom are you shouting?
        Who are you looking at so arrogantly?
            It is Qedosh Yisrael!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Through your servants you defy Adonay and say,
    “With my many chariots I’ll ride up the high mountains,
        up the slopes of Lebanon.
            I’ll cut down its tallest cedars and its finest cypresses.
            I’ll come to its most distant heights
                and its most fertile forests.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I’ll dig wells and drink water.
    I’ll dry up all the streams of Egypt
        with the trampling of my feet.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“‘Haven’t you heard? I did this long ago.
    I planned it in the distant past.
        Now I make it happen so that you will turn fortified cities
            into piles of rubble.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Those who live in these cities are weak, discouraged, and ashamed.
    They will be like plants in the field,
    like fresh, green grass on the roofs,
        dried up by the east wind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I know when you get up and sit down,
    when you go out and come in,
        and how you rage against me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Since you rage against me and your boasting has reached my ears,
    I will put my hook in your nose
        and my bridle in your mouth.
    I will make you go back the way you came.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “‘And this will be a sign for you, Hezekiah: You will eat what grows by itself this year, and the next year you will eat what comes up by itself. But in the third year you will plant and harvest, plant vineyards, and eat what is produced.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Those few people from the nation of Judah who escape will again take root and produce crops.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Those few people will go out from Jerusalem, and those who escape will go out from Mount Zion. Yahweh Tsebaoth is determined to do this.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“This is what Yahweh says about the king of Assyria:
He will never come into this city,
    shoot an arrow here,
    hold a shield in front of it,
        or put up dirt ramps to attack it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He will go back the way he came,
    and he won’t come into this city,”
        declares Yahweh Tsebaoth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“I will shield this city to rescue it for my sake
    and for the sake of my servant David.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yahweh’s angel went out and killed 185,000 soldiers in the Assyrian camp. When the Judeans got up early in the morning, they saw all the corpses.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then King Sennacherib of Assyria left. He went home to Nineveh and stayed there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While he was worshiping in the temple of his god Nisroch, Adrammelech and Sharezer, his sons, assassinated him and escaped to the land of Ararat. His son Esarhaddon succeeded him as king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In those days Hezekiah became sick and was about to die. The prophet Isaiah, son of Amoz, came to him and said, “This is what Yahweh says: Give final instructions to your household, because you’re about to die. You won’t get well.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hezekiah turned to the wall and prayed to Yahweh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Please, Yahweh, remember how I’ve lived faithfully and sincerely in your presence. I’ve done what you consider right.” And he cried bitterly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Yahweh spoke his word to Isaiah,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Go and say to Hezekiah, ‘This is what Yahweh Elohim of your ancestor David says: I’ve heard your prayer. I’ve seen your tears. I’m going to give you 15 more years to live.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I’ll rescue you and defend this city from the control of the king of Assyria.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Isaiah said, “Take a fig cake, and place it over the boil so that the king will get well.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hezekiah asked, “What is the sign that I’ll go to Yahweh’s temple?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Isaiah said, “This is your sign from Yahweh that he will do what he promises.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sun made a shadow that went down the stairway of Ahaz’s upper palace. I’m going to make the shadow go back ten steps.” So the sun on the stairway went back up the ten steps it had gone down.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Hezekiah of Judah wrote this after he was sick and became well again:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I thought that in the prime of my life
    I would go down to the gates of Sheol
        and be robbed of the rest of my life.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I thought that I wouldn’t see Yah in this world.
    Even with all the people in the world,
    I thought I would never see another person.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My life was over.
    You rolled it up like a shepherd’s tent.
    You rolled up my life like a weaver.
    You cut me off from the loom.
        You ended my life in one day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I cried out until morning
    as if a lion had crushed all my bones.
        You ended my life in one day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I chirped like swallows and cranes.
    I cooed like doves.
    My eyes were tired from looking up to heaven.
    I’ve suffered miserably, O Adonay!
        Please help me!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
What can I say now that he has spoken to me?
    He has done this.
    I will be careful the rest of my life because of my bitter experience.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Adonay, people live in spite of such things,
    and I have the will to live in spite of them.
        You give me health and keep me alive.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Now my bitter experience turns into peace.
    You have saved me and kept me from the rotting pit.
        You have thrown all my sins behind you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Sheol doesn’t thank you!
    Death doesn’t praise you!
    Those who go down to the pit cannot expect you to be faithful.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Those who are living praise you as I do today.
    Fathers make your faithfulness known to their children.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yahweh is going to rescue me,
    so let us play stringed instruments.
        We live our lives in Yahweh’s temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At that time Baladan’s son, King Merodach Baladan of Babylon, sent letters and a present to Hezekiah. He had heard that Hezekiah had been sick and had recovered.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hezekiah was so happy with them that he showed the messengers his warehouse: the silver, gold, balsam, fine olive oil, his entire armory, and everything in his treasury. Hezekiah showed them everything in his palace and every corner of his kingdom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then the prophet Isaiah came to King Hezekiah and asked, “What did these men say? And where did they come from?”
Hezekiah answered, “They came to me from the distant country of Babylon.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Isaiah asked, “What did they see in your palace?”
Hezekiah answered, “They saw everything in my palace, and I showed them everything in my treasury.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Isaiah said to Hezekiah, “Hear the word of Yahweh Tsebaoth!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yahweh says, ‘The days are going to come when everything in your palace, everything your ancestors have stored up to this day, will be taken away to Babylon. Nothing will be left.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Some of your own descendants will be taken away. They will become officials in the palace of the king of Babylon.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hezekiah said to Isaiah, “Yahweh’s word that you have spoken is good.” He added, “Just let there be peace and security as long as I live.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Comfort my people! Comfort them!” says your Elohim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Speak tenderly to Jerusalem and announce to it
    that its time of hard labor is over
        and its wrongs have been paid for.
            It has received from Yahweh double for all its sins.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A voice cries out in the desert:
“Clear a way for Yahweh.
    Make a straight highway in the wilderness for our Elohim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Every valley will be raised.
    Every mountain and hill will be lowered.
    Steep places will be made level.
    Rough places will be made smooth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then Yahweh’s glory will be revealed
    and all people will see it together.
        Yahweh has spoken.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A voice called, “Call out!”
I asked, “What should I call out?”
“Call out: All people are like grass,
    and all their beauty is like a flower in the field.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Grass dries up,
    and flowers wither when Yahweh’s breath blows on them.
        Yes, people are like grass.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Grass dries up,
    and flowers wither,
        but the word of our Elohim will last forever.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Go up a high mountain, Zion.
    Tell the good news!
    Call out with a loud voice, Jerusalem.
    Tell the good news!
    Raise your voice without fear.
    Tell the cities of Judah:
        “Here is your Elohim!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Adonay Yahweh is coming with power
    to rule with authority.
    His reward is with him,
    and the people he has won arrive ahead of him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Like a shepherd he takes care of his flock.
    He gathers the lambs in his arms.
    He carries them in his arms.
    He gently helps the sheep and their lambs.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Who has measured the water of the sea with the palm of his hand
    or measured the sky with the length of his hand?
    Who has held the dust of the earth in a bushel basket
    or weighed the mountains on a scale and the hills on a balance?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Who has directed the Ruach Yahweh
    or instructed him as his adviser?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Whom did he consult?
    Who gave him understanding?
        Who taught him the right way?
        Who taught him knowledge?
        Who informed him about the way to understanding?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The nations are like a drop in a bucket
    and are considered to be like dust on a scale.
    The weight of the islands is like fine dust.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
All the trees in Lebanon are not enough to burn an offering.
    Its wild animals are not enough for a single burnt offering.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
All the nations amount to nothing in his presence.
    He considers them less than nothing and worthless.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
To whom, then, can you compare El?
    To what statue can you compare him?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Craftsmen make idols.
    Goldsmiths cover them with gold.
        Silversmiths make silver chains for them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The poorest people choose wood that will not rot
    and search out skillful craftsmen
        to set up idols that will not fall over.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Don’t you know?
    Haven’t you heard?
        Haven’t you been told from the beginning?
            Don’t you understand the foundations of the earth?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
God is enthroned above the earth,
    and those who live on it are like grasshoppers.
    He stretches out the sky like a canopy
    and spreads it out like a tent to live in.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He makes rulers unimportant
    and makes earthly judges worth nothing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They have hardly been planted.
    They have hardly been sown.
    They have hardly taken root in the ground.
    Then he blows on them and they wither,
        and a windstorm sweeps them away like straw.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“To whom, then, can you compare me?
    Who is my equal?” asks the Holy One.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Look at the sky and see.
    Who created these things?
    Who brings out the stars one by one?
        He calls them all by name.
    Because of the greatness of his might and the strength of his power,
    not one of them is missing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Jacob, why do you complain?
    Israel, why do you say,
    “My way is hidden from Yahweh,
        and my rights are ignored by my Elohim”?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Don’t you know?
    Haven’t you heard?
    El Olam, Yahweh, the Creator of the ends of the earth,
    doesn’t grow tired or become weary.
        His understanding is beyond reach.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He gives strength to those who grow tired
    and increases the strength of those who are weak.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Even young people grow tired and become weary,
    and young men will stumble and fall.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yet, the strength of those who wait with hope in Yahweh
    will be renewed.
        They will soar on wings like eagles.
            They will run and won’t become weary.
            They will walk and won’t grow tired.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Be silent and listen to me, you coastlands.
    Let the people gain new strength.
    Let them come near and speak.
    Let us come together for judgment.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Who has raised up from the east
    someone to whom Yahweh gives victory with every step he takes?
        Nations are handed over to him.
            He defeats kings.
            With his sword he turns them into dust.
            With his bow he turns them into straw blown by the wind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He chases them, marching by safely
                on a path his feet have never traveled before.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Who has accomplished this?
    Who has determined the course of history from the beginning?
    I, Yahweh, was there first, and I will be there to the end.
    I am the one!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The coastlands have seen him and are afraid.
    The ends of the earth tremble.
    They have come near and gathered together.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
People help their neighbors
    and say to their relatives, “Be brave!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Craftsmen encourage goldsmiths.
    Metalsmiths encourage blacksmiths who work at their anvils.
    They say that their soldering is good.
        And they fasten things with nails so they won’t move.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“But you are my servant Israel,
    Jacob, whom I have chosen,
    the descendant of Abraham, my dear friend.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I have taken you from the ends of the earth
    and called you from its most distant places.
    I said to you, ‘You are my servant.
    I’ve chosen you; I haven’t rejected you.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Don’t be afraid, because I am with you.
    Don’t be intimidated; I am your Elohim.
    I will strengthen you.
    I will help you.
    I will support you with my victorious right hand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Everyone who is angry with you
    will be ashamed and disgraced.
    Those who oppose you
    will be reduced to nothing and disappear.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You will search for your enemies,
    but you will not find them.
    Those who are at war with you
    will be reduced to nothing and no longer exist.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I, Yahweh your Elohim, hold your right hand
    and say to you, ‘Don’t be afraid; I will help you.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Don’t be afraid, Jacob, you worm.
    You people of Israel, I will help you,”
    declares Yahweh, your Go’el, Qedosh Yisrael.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“I am going to make you into a new threshing sledge
    with sharp, double-edged teeth.
    You will thresh the mountains and crush them to dust.
    You will turn the hills into straw.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You will winnow them.
    The wind will carry them away.
    The windstorm will scatter them.
    But you will find joy in Yahweh
    and praise Qedosh Yisrael.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“The poor and needy are looking for water, but there is none.
    Their tongues are parched with thirst.
    I, Yahweh, will answer them.
    I, the Elohim of Israel, will not abandon them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will make rivers flow on bare hilltops.
    I will make springs flow through valleys.
        I will turn deserts into lakes.
        I will turn dry land into springs.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will plant cedar, acacia, myrtle, and wild olive trees in the desert.
    I will place cedar, fir, and cypress trees together in the wilderness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
People will see and know.
    Together they will consider and understand
    that Yahweh’s power has done this,
    that Qedosh Yisrael has created it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Present your case,” says Yahweh.
    “Bring forward your best arguments,” says Jacob’s Melek.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Bring your idols so they can tell us what’s going to happen.
    Explain past events that your idols told you about
        so that we may consider them
            and know what their outcome will be.
                Tell us about future events.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Tell us what’s going to happen
    so that we may know that you are gods.
    Yes, do something, good or evil,
        to intimidate us and make us afraid.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You are nothing!
    You can’t do anything!
    Whoever chooses you is disgusting.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“I have raised up someone from the north, and he has come.
    He will call on my name from the east.
    He will attack rulers as if they were mud,
        as if he were treading on clay like a potter.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Who revealed this from the beginning so that we could know it?
    Who revealed this from the past so that we could say that he was right?
    No one revealed it.
    No one announced it.
    No one heard your words.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I was the first to tell Zion, ‘Look, here they are.’
    I gave Jerusalem a messenger with the good news.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When I look, there is no one.
    There is no one to advise them.
    When I ask them a question,
    will they give an answer?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
All of them are nothing.
    They can’t do anything.
    Their statues are nothing but air.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Here is my Ebed, whom I support.
    Here is my chosen one, with whom I am pleased.
    I have put my Ruach on him.
    He will bring justice to the nations.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He will not cry out or raise his voice.
    He will not make his voice heard in the streets.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He will not break off a damaged cattail.
    He will not even put out a smoking wick.
    He will faithfully bring about justice.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He will not be discouraged or crushed
    until he has set up justice on the earth.
    The coastlands will wait for his teachings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yahweh El created the heavens and stretched them out.
    He shaped the earth and all that comes from it.
    He gave life to the people who are on it
        and breath to those who walk on it.
This is what Yahweh El says:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I, Yahweh, have called you to do what is right.
    I will take hold of your hand.
    I will protect you.
    I will appoint you as my promise to the people,
        as my light to the nations.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You will give sight to the blind,
                bring prisoners out of prisons,
                    and bring those who live in darkness
    out of dungeons.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I am Yahweh; that is my name.
    I will not give my glory to anyone else
        or the praise I deserve to idols.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
What I said in the past has come true.
    I will reveal new things before they happen.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Sing a new song to Yahweh.
    Sing his praise from the ends of the earth,
    you people who sail on the seas
        and all the creatures that live in them,
    you coastlands and all who live on them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Let those who live in the desert and its cities raise their voices.
    Let those who live in the settlements of Kedar praise him.
    Let those who live in Sela sing for joy.
    Let them shout from the tops of the mountains.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Let them give glory to Yahweh
    and announce his praise on the coastlands.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yahweh marches out like a warrior.
    He prepares himself for battle like a soldier.
        He shouts, gives the battle cry, and overpowers his enemies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I have been silent for a long time.
    I kept quiet and held myself back.
    But like a woman in childbirth I will cry out.
    I will gasp and pant.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will lay waste to mountains and hills.
    I will dry up all their vegetation.
    I will turn rivers into islands.
    I will dry up ponds.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will lead the blind on unfamiliar roads.
    I will lead them on unfamiliar paths.
    I will turn darkness into light in front of them.
    I will make rough places smooth.
    These are the things I will do for them,
        and I will never abandon them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then those who trust idols
    and those who say to statues,
        “You are our gods”
    will be turned away and put to shame.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Listen, you deaf people.
    Look, you blind people, so that you can see.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Who is blind except my servant
    or deaf like the messenger I send?
    Who is blind like the one who has my trust
    or blind like the servant of Yahweh?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You have seen much, but you do not observe anything.
    Your ears are open, but you hear nothing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yahweh is pleased because he does what is right.
    He praises the greatness of his teachings and makes them glorious.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But these people are robbed and looted.
    They are all trapped in pits and hidden in prisons.
        They have become prey with no one to rescue them.
            They have become loot with no one to say, “Give it back.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Who among you will listen to this?
    Is there anyone who will pay attention and listen in the future?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Who gave Jacob away as loot
    and handed Israel over to robbers?
    Wasn’t it Yahweh, against whom we have sinned?
    They didn’t want to live his way.
    They didn’t obey his teachings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So he poured out his burning anger and the horrors of war on them.
    It engulfed them in flames, but they did not understand.
    It burned them, but they did not take it to heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yahweh created Jacob and formed Israel. Now, this is what Yahweh says:
Do not be afraid, because I have reclaimed you.
    I have called you by name; you are mine.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When you go through the sea, I am with you.
    When you go through rivers, they will not sweep you away.
    When you walk through fire, you will not be burned,
    and the flames will not harm you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I am Yahweh your Elohim, Qedosh Yisrael, your Savior.
    Egypt is the ransom I exchanged for you.
    Sudan and Seba are the price I paid for you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Since you are precious to me, you are honored and I love you.
    I will exchange others for you.
        Nations will be the price I pay for your life.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not be afraid, because I am with you.
    I will bring your descendants from the east
        and gather you from the west.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will say to the north, “Give them up,”
    and to the south, “Do not keep them.”
    Bring my sons from far away
    and my daughters from the ends of the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Bring everyone who is called by my name,
    whom I created for my glory,
    whom I formed and made.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Bring the people who are blind but still have eyes,
    the people who are deaf but still have ears.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
All nations have gathered together, and people have assembled.
